TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question by expressing the regret and concern of the Opposition to hear of the sudden illness of Senator Chipp. I take this opportunity to wish him a speedy and full recovery. I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the fact that his Government has consistently argued that sustained economic growth is the only way to reduce unemployment. In formulating the 1981-82 Budget, the Government clearly saw the economic growth of late 1980 as threatening excessive wage growth. In view of the fact that the Government's reaction to economic growth was to seek to dampen wages growth by depressing the economy and increasing unemployment, is it not fair to say that this Government's stated aim of reducing unemployment by encouraging sustained economic growth is wrong? Would it not be more accurate to say that the Government's strategy, as revealed in this Budget, is to seek to build further economic growth on a foundation of sustained unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intrude also to indicate that Government members are concerned to learn of Senator Chipp's temporary ill health. We wish him well and a speedy return. I now direct my attention to the question. The answer is, of course, emphatically no. When the Budget was introduced last year the Australian Labor Party said, along with ' ''We'll all be rooned,'' said Hanrahan', that everything that could possibly happen, from german measles to polio, would happen from that Budget. In fact, that Budget resulted in a 2 per cent fall in inflation and a significant growth in real employment. It did the things that the Government said it would do. What is more, it was applauded by countries overseas.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer is therefore no, it is not our intention to move to get increased growth by more unemployment. In fact, as has been demonstrated, increased growth will create more employment. The Budget's main thrust is to so demolish the deficit, to get a substantial reduction overall in the total deficit, that the Government's intrusion into the borrowing market in Australia will be less and there will be more room for enterprise to borrow in the market. This will take the heat off interest rates and provide more money for capital investment, more jobs and more expansion. That is the basic thrust of the Budget. We will have exactly the same Jeremiahs as last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is it not the same as last year?

—In response to the interjection one should note that the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development is even more optimistic than the Government. The OECD sees Australia in the year ahead as having a growth rate of something like 5.5 per cent. We are more modest but nevertheless we are on target, well ahead of the rest of the world.

Materials used in the course of the manufacture of goods such as yachts are exempt from tax and this will not be changed by the proposals in this present Budget. —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. In view of the great importance of the export beef trade both to the nation and to producers, has the Government done all it can do as rapidly as possible to restore confidence in the Australian export beef trade? Has the Government withdrawn the export licence from the company or companies concerned? Has an embargo been placed on the export of all beef pending verification of its contents, and indeed has it established the bona fides of the verification process beyond all doubt?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure the honourable senator and the Senate that the Government is doing all within its powers to deal with what is a very serious matter for Australia and for a major export industry. I have answered a number of questions on this matter since Parliament resumed, and the Minister for Primary Industry has, I think, been keeping the public as well as the Parliament closely informed as to action being taken by the Government and by the United States Government.

ANSWER.PARA: I have a copy of the latest Press release on the matter which was put out by the Minister for Primary Industry this morning and which details some of the more recent action which has been taken. I would like to draw attention to the major points in that Press release, which I think go to the main points raised by the honourable senator in his question. The Press release pointed out that the inquiries so far have indicated infringements only with respect to Establishment 140C-that is, the premises known as Profreeze in Richmond, Victoria-which was deregistered on 13 August 1981. The release stated:
All known product from this establishment has now been seized for testing.

Following the detection and advice from the United States on 11 August 1981 of horsemeat in export packs from this works, a most intensive investigation and tightening of surveillance has been initiated in Australia. Australian authorities have been in close contact with their counterparts in the United States, and the US government has acknowledged the ready co-operation of the Australian government and its determination to stamp out illegal practice.
Mr Nixon said the US Government had now advised the following procedures to more rigidly prevent any attempt at substitution of beef for the United States market:
The Press release outlined measures which are being taken in the United States as follows:
1. All stocks of Australian meat at present in the United States are to be held and sampled for substitution infringements.
2. Further consignments of Australian meat to the US will be species sampled on arrival before release.
3. The Australian Bureau of Animal health will set up an approved procedure for species testing in Australia before export meat receives its final certification.

The investigations by the Australian Federal Police are proceeding and are described by the Minister as satisfactory. The Minister has indicated that he is determined that prosecutions should be launched wherever possible. Various immediate measures have also been taken by the Australian Bureau of Animal Health to tighten final export surveillance. There is additional spot checking of meat products in all States, extra meat inspector surveillance at cold stores and shiploading scrutiny and intensive checking of certificates and documentation. Other measures not yet in operation but under urgent investigation include new processes for sealing, stamping and certification of export cartons and greater security over meat transfers, boning rooms, cold stores and trucking to dockside. These matters are all being discussed with the United States authorities in the hope that mutually satisfactory arrangements can be made.

I do not have advice on the point raised by the honourable senator with respect to export licences. But as I indicated earlier in my response, all of the products have been seized and I think I can say, without having any direct information, that there would be no licence to export meat from those works until the whole matter has been cleared up. I would stress to the Senate that the matter is for quite obvious reasons regarded with great seriousness by the Commonwealth Government, as it is by all meat exporters, and every effort is being made to ensure that the matter is cleared up as quickly as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Yesterday my colleague Senator Haines addressed a question concerning the de facto imposition of a new sales tax on food by taxing the materials in which it is wrapped. Will the Minister give some information on another new proposed sales tax which again is to be imposed on a family necessity-building materials. Is it a fact that this tax will increase the cost of most houses started after the end of the year by $500 to $1,000? In what way does the Government see this as anti-inflationary? Will this measure not add a final coup de grace to the hopes of those thousands of young people whose prospects of ever owning a house have been severely reduced by the recent disastrous increase in interest rates?

—I think this question should properly be addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. However, I will take the question on board. It so happens that I am in the process of reading at this very time a publication put out by the Premier of New South Wales who is also the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party. In the publication he writes about the boom in the domestic housing industry. That may not be true. Perhaps we should wait for the statements of the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party in the weeks immediately ahead. I do not know what the impact of the 2 1/2 per cent sales tax will be in terms of cost of an average house. I am prepared to find out and let the honourable senator know. The overall cost of a house is governed primarily not by sales tax but by the rate of inflation in Australia. The ability of the Government to reduce inflation by 2 per cent last year was of enormous benefit to those who in those circumstances were purchasing a house. It is true that the imposition of additional sales tax will add perceptibly to the cost of a house but in no way can it compare with the great value got from a reduction in inflation. The Budget sets out to reduce and to contain inflation and interest rates in Australia. It is towards that end that the thrust of the Budget is made. In looking at the Budget one looks not at just the one factor of home ownership but at the whole range of factors. The greatest benefit that we can give to a potential home owner in Australia is to reduce inflation, and that is the Government's aim.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION: RELOCATION OF AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY OFFICE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Education refers to the relocation from Civic to Woden of the Australian Capital Territory office of the Commonwealth Department of Education. Is it a fact that the standard of service at the Australian Capital Territory office will be curtailed as a result of this decision or rather as a result of the bans on eligibility checks which have been instituted by certain staff members of that office?

—Specific decisions were taken to reduce staffing within the Department of Education following an extensive review of all departmental programs As a result of staff ceiling reductions for this year the Department of Education reduced the level of services in a number of program areas. As a consequence it was decided to relocate the Australian Capital Territory office of the Department of Education to the MLC Tower in Woden which houses the central office of the Education Department. Relocation of the Australian Capital Territory office will enable the Department to make use of common service facilities. However, care has been taken to preserve the Department's identity and its autonomy. Whilst some inconvenience to some Australian Capital Territory students will arise from the relocation of the Australian Capital Territory office it will remain more accessible to Australian Capital Territory students than most other State offices to their client groups. The course of action chosen was considered preferable to other options which would have affected more directly the availability of educational services to students in the Australian Capital Territory. It should be pointed out that Australian Capital Territory office staffing has been calculated on a work load basis. Service to the client group will remain at a standard similar to that provided by other State offices.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer or, alternatively, to the Attorney-General if he should regard it as more in his line. I ask: What arrangements have been made for the repayment to wholesalers, manufacturers and importers-not to mention those to whom the costs have been passed on-of the increases in sales tax paid by them since Budget night in the event that the Parliament fails to pass the legislation authorising those increases? Also, is it the case that the Commonwealth proposes to rely on the legal doctrine that moneys paid under a mistake of law are irrecoverable, and that the Commonwealth will make no such reimbursement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of any such arrangements having been made. In fact, I am rather surprised to hear a question of that kind by Senator Evans, in view of some of his rhetoric of past years with regard to circumstances that would lead to the situation that he now espouses. I repeat, I am not aware of any arrangements that have been made, given the supposition posed in his question, and I believe that we should wait to see the outcome of events.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, relates to the Whale Protection Bill which, despite its successful passage through the Parliament in May 1980, has yet to be proclaimed. Does the Minister agree that the initiatives contained in the Bill have contributed substantially to Australia's good reputation in environmental circles on matters relating to whaling? If so, why has the Bill not been proclaimed? Also, when will the Bill be proclaimed so that we may ensure that Australia's firm commitment to the protection of whales is not jeopardised in any way?

—Senator Missen's question is in two parts: The first is as to why the delay in proclamation has occurred and the second is as to when proclamation is likely to take place. The Whale Protection Bill, which was passed by Parliament in May 1980, prohibited all whaling off the Australian coast in the 200-mile fishing zone. However, it has since been desirable to exchange with the States and the Northern Territory correspondence seeking the introduction of complementary legislation and complementary arrangements with regard to the territorial seas. I understand that following consultation with all States and the Northern Territory on the arrangements for administration of the legislation, action is now being taken to proclaim it. In short, it is my understanding that proclamation has been delayed because of the need for consultation, that such consultation has now been completed and that proclamation should not be long delayed.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, is supplementary to that asked by Senator Mason. I ask: Is it a fact that a very modest house in Tasmania which a week ago could have been built and furnished for $35,000 would now cost $800 more due to the imposition of 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on building materials and furnishings? Is it a fact that interest rates for home buyers have increased by at least one per cent in the past fortnight? Can the Minister explain how these deliberate decisions of the Government help Tasmanian home builders to share in the promised prosperity of the resources boom, or are Tasmanian home builders being asked to bear the burden of unsuccessfully competing with the financing of huge resources projects in other parts of Australia?
—I am not aware that--
—Tell us how to reduce inflation while you are at it.

—If Senator Grimes were to listen he might learn. For example, since interest rates have been mentioned, let me give the trend since 1978. If in 1978 a person had taken out a housing mortgage loan of $30,000 at 10 per cent, at current interest rates he would now be paying $54 a month more. His average weekly wage would have risen in that time by $221, so since we are being asked how the economy can benefit the home owner--
—Don't you change the Hansard on that statement. You said $221 weekly.

—If I said weekly, I meant monthly. I will say it again for Senator Grimes's benefit because he no doubt would like to hear it. A mortgage of $30,000 taken out in 1978 at an interest rate of 10 per cent would now attract an increase of $54 a month in interest payments. By the same token, in the same period the average weekly wage has risen by $221 a month. There has been a significant rise in real wages. Last year inflation ran at 8.8 per cent and average weekly wages rose by in excess of 13 per cent. So there was a net gain in real purchasing power to the average person. We do not wish interest rates to rise. In fact, the thrust of the Budget, as I have said, is directed towards abating interest rates. The real test for people is: Are the living standards of the people of Australia improving? Based on the figures of recent years, they are improving demonstrably. Over the period since 1978 the rate of growth in new housing in Australia has improved demonstrably, and last year there was a highly significant increase in house building. If we want to compete in this matter we have to keep down inflation and interest rates. Then we can pass on real value to the people of Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I draw the Minister's attention to an article which appeared in today's Courier-Mail wherein it is alleged that the National Party member for the State seat of Caboolture, when debating amendments to the liquor legislation, said:

QUESTION.PARA: It should be an offence for hotels to sell liquor to Aboriginals as they can't hold their liquor.

I preface my question by saying that this same man, Mr Frawley, was a vocal supporter of the Springbok tour of New Zealand. He also publicly stated that he could not care less whether there was an African boycott of the Commonwealth Games. Does the Minister agree that those sentiments appear to be very similar to those of the Premier of Queensland? From the Minister's dealings with the Premier and other National Party Ministers, are those sentiments representative of the general views of the State of Queensland in its treatment of the Aboriginal population?

TALK.START.PARA: —The essential part of the honourable senator's question really revolves around the fact that any Australian should have found it necessary to make a statement of the kind that was quoted in the newspaper. I dissociate myself from that view. The many Aboriginals I know and with whom I drink hold their liquor just as other Australians do. I think most people in this chamber would take the same view. It is not my intention to involve myself in any argument about particular politicians because I am not sure that that will help Aboriginal people. I should like to make two points. The first is that views in society which have come down from previous generations do change, even though they change very slowly, and they will change on this as on other matters. The other point I make is that, whatever we say about the State of Queensland and whatever people want to say in criticism of the State, it should be remembered that out of that State's funds it spends more on Aboriginal affairs than does any other State in the Commonwealth.
—Yes, but it has more Aborigines too.
—Well, that is true.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer able to confirm or deny very serious and persistent reports that the Iwasaki Sangyo Trading Company (Australia) Ltd is using nominee companies to purchase parcels of land in Queensland? Is the Treasurer aware that a number of Australian employees of the Iwasaki Sangyo Company have been observed fencing individual paddocks within the boundaries of the property adjoining Mr Iwasaki's Yeppoon resort property-the same property that Mr Iwasaki was prohibited from buying on 23 January 1980 under the Foreign Takeovers Act 1975, and which was subsequently bought by Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd, a company that came into existence with two $1 shareholders approximately two weeks after the prohibition order was issued? Is the Treasurer further aware that recently more than 150 head of Mr Iwasaki's cattle were grazing on the same property and that these cattle were returnd to the Iwasaki property immediately after an alleged caution from Canberra to Iwasaki Sangyo in Yeppoon? Is it a fact that Mr Iwasaki intends to build an abattoir on his existing tourist resort property at Yeppoon? If so, why? Will the Treasurer order an investigation into the land dealings and business objectives of Iwasaki Sangyo (Aust.) Pty Ltd?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The honourable senator has given a lot of information and has made many statements in his question. He has also ranged fairly widely across an area on which I have no information with me. I will refer to the Treasurer the matters raised by the honourable senator and seek information and also perhaps verify, or otherwise, some of the statements that he has made.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. In view of the wonderful variety and quality of gemstones now produced in Australia, will the Minister consider introducing a precious stones Act which could lay down a code of required business conduct for those involved in the industry in order that the interests of the purchaser, retailer and manufacturer are safeguarded?

—I understand that the need for a code of ethics controlling business activities in precious stones was discussed recently at a meeting of the Standing Committee of Ministers for Consumer Affairs which comprises Commonwealth, State and the Territory consumer affairs Ministers. As a result of decisions reached at a meeting in 1979, I understand, the South Australian authorities did initiate work to develop a framework for model legislation, although I think it was in regard to opals in particular. It is understood that this work is still going forward. I think it would be worth while for Senator Archer to refer his interest in the matter to the Minister. Also, he may care to take up the matter with the South Australian authorities to determine their position at present.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Since we are nearing the end of the International Year of Disabled Persons I wonder whether the Minister is aware of how popular the new pushbutton telephone is to those disabled people, such as the blind, who have always experienced difficulty with the normal dial telephone. Is the Minister also aware that the additional rental and changeover charges for the pushbutton telephone are in excess of $70, which is prohibitive for most pensioners who are anxious to acquire one? What action will the Minister take to enable all disabled persons to acquire a pushbutton telephone free of charge or at a nominal cost?

—I am interested to hear from Senator Sibraa that the pushbutton telephone has been judged to be a success by people who are sight impaired. I take it that the honourable senator is suggesting that it gives them greater access into society. I think my colleague would want to know that, would want to consider the point which the honourable senator has raised and would want to take on board specifically the question of whether the extra rental that is charged might be examined for that group of people to whom the honourable senator has referred, bearing in mind this is the International Year of Disabled Persons.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I refer to the Visual Arts Board which is a part of the Australia Council and is funded by the Commonwealth Government. Is it true that the Visual Arts Board for many years has made grants only for abstract or experimental artists and not for realist or traditional artists despite the creativity and the wider popularity of the latter with the majority of the Australian people? Is it also true that there has been a similar bias in art purchases for the National Gallery? Why has this bias arisen? How can it be justified? Has it been drawn to the Minister's attention that Mr Paul Fitzgerald, a man of great integrity and experience and the President of the Australian Guild of Realist Artists, in a recent letter to the Australian newspaper took up this matter when he wrote:

QUESTION.PARA: Of all the members of the VAB since its inception, I know of only one whose sympathies I would consider are with traditional art forms . . .
As to the grants, the facts speak for themselves.
He went on to say that in the last published list, of October 1980, 71 artists were mentioned as recipients of help and grants. He continued:
Thirty-six of these are unknown to me. ALL of the 35 known are abstract, semi-abstract or experimental.
Will the Minister completely review this matter and make appropriate provision for realist and traditional artists?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will certainly refer to my colleague the question of a possible review. I do not know what Senator Teague means when he talks about traditional art forms. Perhaps he is talking about nothing but the Claude Lorraine school of art works. I am sure he does not mean that. I am not certain whether there is bias in the purchasing of art works but I will refer that to the Minister. I think it might be appropriate to refer the Senate to a ruling made by one of your predecessors, Mr President, when someone asked about dress. If I remember correctly, on that occasion Sir Magnus Cormack said: 'De gustibus non est disputandum'. I think that what applied then might well apply in relation to the purchase of art forms.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I refer to the Industries Assistance Commission's recommendations for a 10 per cent cut in protection for Australian produced motor cars and the 2 1/2 per cent sales tax increase announced in the Budget. Is the Minister aware of the importance of the motor vehicle industry to the South Australian economy? Nearly 20 per cent of the manufacturing industry work force is involved in motor vehicle or motor vehicle component manufacture.

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware that if the IAC recommendations were adopted a total of 12,000 jobs in the car assembly lines and a further 8,000 jobs in the component industries would be lost, resulting in a massive 50 per cent increase in the unemployment rate in South Australia? The South Australian Minister of Industrial Affairs, Mr Brown, stated that through multiplier effects a further 80,000 jobs would be threatened in South Australia. Is the Minister able to give an estimate of the likely decrease in new Australian made motor vehicle sales which will result from the sales tax increase? Is the Minister prepared to give an undertaking that the Government will not under any circumstances implement these proposals and will reconsider its decision to impose an additional 2 1/2 per cent sales tax on motor vehicles?

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Social Security say what arrangements have been made to ensure that pensioners are acquainted with income test changes for pensioner rental assistance and how many pensioners will benefit from the increase in the maximum rate of rental assistance from $5 to $8 a week?

—I do not have to hand the figures requested by the honourable senator but they are readily available and I will try to get them for her by the end of Question Time. Virtually all of those who are entitled to benefit will already be in receipt of supplementary assistance when the change is effected. As a result, it will be a comparatively straightforward matter to get in touch with those pensioners and to ensure that their entitlements are assessed in advance of the change which is to be made with respect to supplementary assistance. We are particularly concerned to meet the additional needs of those pensioners who are paying very high rent, who are at the moment limited to assistance of $5, and in relation to whom the amount of assistance will rise under this change to a maximum of $8. I assure the honourable senator and the Senate that we will be moving to ensure that all those eligible do receive their entitlement.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. What are the guidelines used by Australia Post in determining the removal of post boxes? Are the distance from the nearest post office, the availability of transport and the needs of aged residents taken into consideration? Are local residents consulted and is a social impact study undertaken, or is the value of a post box measured purely in economic terms?

—I believe I answered this question last session in response to a question from another honourable senator. I will look up that answer and see whether I can make it available to Senator Hearn. I do not believe it picked up the question of whether a social impact study is made. I do not think there is. I believe the other relevant matters the honourable senator raised-for example, the distance which aged persons might have to walk and the distance from transport-and other factors which might be important are taken into account. I will obtain further information for the honourable senator on the matter.

—I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Transport to the old Second World War hangar which serves as the international and domestic air terminal in Darwin and to the chaotic conditions which exist there. I refer also to the limited tarmac area and the overcrowded car parking areas. Can the Minister advise what progress has been made in the planning stages of the resiting and construction of the new terminal in Darwin, the estimated cost of the project and when it is planned to be completed?

—I have some information on the matter raised by Senator Kilgariff. The Government has approved in principle the relocation of all civil aviation activities to the northern side of the main runway by 1985. I understand that the cost of that will be between $40m and $45m in July 1980 prices. A co-ordinating committee has been established comprising the Commonwealth, the Territory and local governments to oversee the whole project. In addition, I understand a public information program will be undertaken. It is to be hoped that that is successful in explaining the reasons for the move from the civil airport to the northern side of the Royal Australian Air Force base. I understand further that detailed planning is being undertaken on those new facilities at present but I am afraid that I cannot indicate at this stage at what time the project might be completed.

—I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs whether it is a fact that, as reported, the Sacred Sites Protection Program in the Northern Territory is in jeopardy because of a shortage of funds. Since the Federal Government has passed the implementation of this Program to the Northern Territory Government, is the problem the result of insufficient funds being made available to the Northern Territory by the Federal Government or an inadequate allocation by the Northern Territory Government to the Program from a bulk grant covering a number of areas?

—The Budget of the Northern Territory was brought down only yesterday. I am dependent upon reports in this morning's radio programs for the information which I have available. I understand that the Sacred Sites Protection Authority in the Northern Territory is funded by the Northern Territory Government and that it has allocated cash to the Authority this year. It was indicated on this morning's radio programs that it might be the same cash. If that is the case, that is a budgetary decision of the Northern Territory Government which now has authority for the Sacred Sites Protection Authority. I remind the Senate that the Authority is established under Northern Territory legislation-that is, the Sacred Sites Ordinance-that the Authority is located in the Northern Territory, in Darwin, and it covers only the Northern Territory. It is a matter which should be resolved in the Territory and by the Territory.

—Mr President I ask a supplementary question. Is it not a fact that the Northern Territory Government implements this program on behalf of the Federal Government and that the Federal Government actually makes the money available for this program?

—Formerly the money was provided through the vote of my Department and passed over to the Northern Territory as it was a States grant fund. As a decision of the Review of Commonwealth Functions it was determined that the funding of the Authority and certain other functions would be more appropriately carried out by the Northern Territory Government and the funding was transferred to the Northern Territory from 1 July 1981. Although there are provisions in the Northern Territory ordinance for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to be responsible for some elements of the Authority's operations, these were temporary provisions only for the transition period towards self-government and they are to be changed by the Northern Territory Government. It is not true to say that I am responsible or will be responsible for certain elements of the operation of the ordinance. It is true to say that following the RCF decisions the funding itself was transferred to the Northern Territory.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The Taxation Board of Review in 1981 Australian Tax Cases, N. 20, held that a loss on the sale of shares within 12 months of acquisition should be allowed as a deduction under section 52, but that any loss arising on the sale outside the 12 months period should not be allowed. I ask: Was it the Government's intention in enacting section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which provides for profits to be assessable on property disposed of within 12 months of acquisition, that a loss should also be allowable? If not, does the Government intend to legislate to reverse this decision of the Taxation Board of Review?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have noted the Taxation Board of Review case that was mentioned by Senator Watson. I would need to refer it to the Treasurer to see whether he intends to take any action arising from that decision or any other action that may be appropriate in the circumstances that were mentioned. I will see that this matter has the Treasurer's attention and that Senator Watson is advised.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Is the Minister prepared to instruct the Commonwealth Electoral Officer to make enrolment forms for the Commonwealth electoral roll available at all polling booths for the forthcoming elections for the National Aboriginal Conference? Does the Minister agree that if enrolment forms were available at all booths, together with information about enrolment procedures, many Aboriginals who live in remote areas and have little opportunity to exercise their right to enrol could be enfranchised if they so chose?
—I take it that the thrust of the honourable senator's question is to try to make use of the occasion of the NAC triennial election to enrol people as Commonwealth electors?
—To give them the choice to enrol.

—I would like to see the maximum enrolment of Aboriginal people as Commonwealth voters. I understand the honourable senator's question. The short answer to her question is no, it is not possible administratively to do as she suggests. I cannot answer so far as enrolment for State elections is concerned, but the position in respect of Federal elections is that the Commonwealth Electoral Act gives Aboriginals the right to choose whether they wish to enrol as electors. That right is to be exercised freely. Indeed, it is an offence against the Act to interfere or attempt to interfere with the free exercise by an Aboriginal of his or her choice whether to enrol. There is some real concern as to whether affirmative action at the polling places during the NAC election may infringe that section of the Act. The Australian Electoral Office will not be using the National Aboriginal Conference election to conduct any program or campaign aimed at the enrolment of Aboriginals or which might otherwise be seen as attempting to influence their enrolment. The Electoral Office believes that it is bound by those provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister consider that by providing enrolment forms and information at booths the Chief Australian Electoral Officer would be acting within the provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act in the same way as he is acting when he sends enrolment forms to householders in urban areas, which those people are invited to fill out to maintain their position on the rolls?
—I thought the first words of the honourable senator's question were: 'Is the Minister willing to instruct the Australian Electoral Office?' I may have misheard the words that followed.
—That is right. Those were the words.

—If it is merely the provision of forms, that may be another question, provided there is no action to try to do something contrary to any provision of the Electoral Act in regard to influencing people to enrol.

—Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister aware that the Reagan Administration in the United States of America has set up a task force, chaired by the Vice-President, to examine the great mass of government regulations in the United States with a view to eliminating the redundant ones? Is it a fact that the task force has found that many of the regulations are not only redundant but also actually hamper economic activity without any commensurate social benefit? Is it not very likely that we also have a large number of obsolete, redundant and damaging rules and regulations? Has the Government considered the possibility of a thorough clean-out of superfluous regulations, which would have to be done by deliberate and sustained Government policy as it would never be initiated by the Public Service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hamer has asked me four individual questions. First, I am aware that--
—It is a tendentious question.

—The devil cites scripture for his purpose there, if I may say so. I am aware that in January of this year President Reagan announced the establishment of a presidential task force on regulatory relief, headed by Vice-President George Bush. The aim was to review existing and proposed regulations and to oversee the development of legislative proposals to ensure that further regulations are kept to a minimum. As I understand it, in June this year the President made a statement on the work of this task force in which he commented that as a result of that work 'many needless and unproductive regulations have been eliminated'. He went on:

ANSWER.PARA: Other officials in my Administration are moving forward with equal vigor and are producing tangible results. Regulatory relief actions to date have resulted in billions of dollars in savings to the American people.

President Reagan made those comments. Our Government is aware of the concern expressed at the extent of government regulation in Australia and it has taken steps in this area. Recently announced decisions arising from the Review of Commonwealth Functions indicate the Government's resolve to achieve a more efficient and economic administration and minimise Commonwealth intrusion into the private sector. For example, these decisions relate to the abolition of the Prices Justification Tribunal, reduction in the functions of the Trade Practices Commission, and the general reduction in the paper burden on industry. It is hoped that the States, and indeed local government, will follow the example set by the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth Government will ensure that further growth in Commonwealth regulations is kept to a minimum and will continue to examine the need for existing regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. I ask: Did the Australian Electoral Office conduct a survey of informal voting at the 1977 election? Was a survey of the times at which people voted carried out by the same office at the 1980 Federal election? Have the results of these surveys been conveyed to the Minister and the Government? Can the Minister say why these reports have not been made public and available to the Parliament for consideration?

—There are three parts to Senator Gietzelt's question and each will require reference to the Minister for Administrative Services. As to whether a report has gone to that Minister, only the Minister can answer. As to whether and when a report is to be made public, only the Minister can answer. I am aware, as honourable senators are aware, that the Australian Electoral Office usually records informal voting. The honourable senator asks whether a study was done in 1980 similar to that which was done in 1977. I will try to obtain that information for him.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to the tremendous damage being caused to Australia's reputation as a reliable international trading partner by industrial disputes which are interfering with our exports.
—What about the meat racket?
—Not to mention horse meat.

—That is not helping either. Is the Minister aware of statements made on Monday by Mr Bowen, the executive director of the Chamber of Shipping (Australian), in an appeal to the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions for help in resolving industrial disputes? Mr Bowen said that more than 60 ships around Australia were being delayed by industrial disputes or union bans and that the industry was losing $1m a day, while the loss in exports added many millions of dollars to that figure, to say nothing of the loss of jobs and employment opportunities. As many of these disputes involve demarcation arguments between unions, has the Government considered altering the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to ensure--
—They do not, you know.
—A lot of them do.
—No.
—What about Western Australia? It is a classic example!
—You said most of them.

—I said many of them. As that is the case, has the Government considered altering the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to encourage these disputes being resolved by the ACTU and to prevent such industrial disputation spreading to the detriment of the welfare of other workers not involved?

—The honourable senator raises in his question a matter which is of serious concern to the Government and, indeed, to many exporters. I think most honourable senators would be aware that a substantial number of ships are tied up around Australia because of a series of industrial disputes. The number of those ships has increased recently and I think is presently between 60 and 80. I am sorry I do not have a more precise figure for the information of the Senate. I think it is true that a number of the current disputes arise out of demarcation issues.
—The grain handling. What other one?

—Senator Harradine is being of great assistance to me in drawing my attention to the fact that the grain handling dispute is of that nature. I was simply seeking to confirm what was put forward by the honourable senator in his question-that demarcation disputes are one area which is causing a problem. I want to consider further the matter of whether amendment to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act would provide a solution. I will refer the question asked by the honourable senator to Mr Viner and get a reply from him as soon as possible.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. In view of the resources tax of up to $7 a tonne levied by other countries on producers of bauxite, will the Minister explain why the average royalty on Australian bauxite is only 88c a tonne? Has the Government considered raising the Australian royalty to a realistic level? If not, will the Minister explain why the Government prefers to impose inflationary taxes on basic goods rather than tax the bauxite industry at anything like world rates? Can the Minister justify the refusal of his Government to seek a realistic return to the Australian people for the resources which are being extracted from Australia.?

—If Senator Siddons is referring to royalties, I say that royalties basically are imposed by the States. They are a State tax. I do not narrow the matter to that because I understand the general thrust of the honourable senator's question. However, to the extent that he asked a question about royalties, that would be a matter for the individual States. As he may know, for example, Queensland imposes considerable royalties and also types of royalties in terms of freight rates. Whether or not the particular resource taken from the ground is taxed sufficiently depends on whether we get a world price for it. The first job we have to do is to sell it at world price. We then have to ensure that throughout the whole movement of bauxite from the ground to its sale the range of local, State and Federal taxes is sufficient to take what is an optimum amount. At the moment the Commonwealth Government's policies on taxation are directed towards other forms of taxation, including company tax. It would be a matter entirely for budgetary policy, and therefore a policy matter, for the Government to change that. The Government has in fact imposed an export levy on coal. Because the production of coal has expanded enormously recently the Government has continued that levy. The people of Australia are sharing in it. For the time being at least the Government has not taken any such step with bauxite. It will seek through the variety of other taxes-local, State and Federal-to return the true value of the resources to the people of Australia.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The management of resources development by the Federal Government.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Victoria-Leader of the Opposition) (3.45)-This matter of public importance relates to bad management, bad government and the credibility of governments. I will begin by taking the classic example in the Fraser Ministry of credibility, or incredibility, by referring to the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Sir Phillip Lynch. At the outset I say that he has never been renowned for being a subtle chap but he typifies a government whose overriding instinct has been to hang on to office, if necessary through the seat, misrepresentation or shonky figures.

SPEECH.PARA: As Treasurer of this country, Lynch introduced a new word into the lexicon of Australian politics. The word was 'rubbery'. He used rubbery figures in his Budgets and he has been using rubbery figures ever since. It is a tragic fact for the language of Australian parliamentarians that that has now become a word freely used. The Minister excelled himself in the matter of the so-called resources boom. He had many friends in this Government when he excelled himself in those matters. Before the last election Ministers in the Fraser Government were swapping figures around like drunks at a horse sale, boosting the value of the resources boom with blinding speed. I reiterate that that was before the election. In a matter of days they moved more figures than a window dresser at the Myer emporium would move in a year. It is not surprising that Sir Phillip Lynch was at the top of the heap in this process. He is the man who made his mark in politics with the Stumpy Gully estate.

As Minister for Industry and Commerce Sir Phillip Lynch topped off the value of the resources boom by citing a figure of $33 billion. According to the figures which he provided that amount was to have been invested in the boom. Let us take that as the top figure suggested. Let us ignore for a moment the statement he made on 2 June this year when he got totally carried away and talked about a $50 billion boom over 10 years from private investment alone. He went on to say that the potential benefits would include a one to one percentage point increase in the gross domestic product, continued strong growth in resource-based exports and potentially more job opportunities.

I will illustrate in quite a simple way, from the point of view of a member of parliament, what that sort of proposition means and what that sort of talk by a Minister in the Government means. On several occasions last year I visited the provincial town of Ballarat in Victoria. The people of that town and its council are very concerned about unemployment and about industry, the two matters, of course, being intimately related. What they did on my advice and the advice of Liberal parliamentarians who used to visit Ballarat was to set up, as it were, a inquiry related to industry in that town. The inquiry was to look at how, because of the enormous resources boom about to take place, prophets of which were people such as Sir Phillip Lynch, the people of Ballarat could change the structure of industry to make it more responsive to this resources boom and what they would do about employment in the city of Ballarat to make it move responsive to this enormous resources boom which was said by Ministers in the Fraser Government to be upon us.

That sort of mini-experience I had in visiting Ballarat and discussing those issues must have been replicated time and time again across this country as the resources boom was talked up, and people who were very concerned about the future of their communities in terms of industry, employment, training and educational institutions and so on were encouraged to believe that this El Dorado was upon us and that they would have a share in that El Dorado if only they very quickly adjusted their economies to the scale which was espoused by Sir Phillip Lynch and which was talked about so freely. I said that he had said only on 2 June this year that the benefits of the boom would be a one per cent to 2 per cent increase in gross domestic product, a continued strong growth in resource-based exports and potentially more job opportunities. As is usual, I doubt that he consulted the rest of the Ministry before making these extraordinary prognostications.

A couple of weeks after Sir Phillip Lynch had spoken in these glowing terms the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs (Mr N. A. Brown) said that in his opinion resource projects would not solve the unemployment problems. I remind any subsequent speaker in this debate that the Opposition has been asking questions in the Senate about that matter for two years now. I have put the questions on notice and have asked questions of Senator Carrick on numerous occasions when he has talked glibly in this place about the multiplier effect of resource developments. Let us see the figures for the multiplier effects and what they will mean in terms of their impact on unemployment in Australia. We have never seen the figures; they do not exist. The figures upon which it is all based are, to use Sir Phillip Lynch's expression, rubbery figures. The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, Mr Brown-admittedly he is a new, young, active Minister-said with characteristic honesty, if I might say so, that resources projects would not solve the unemployment problems. That was something Mr Street said 2 1/2 years ago, and he was sacked as Minister for Industrial Relations for doing so. That is the level of credibility of this Government and its level of agreement and understanding of what we are really talking about in relation to these matters.

Sir Phillip Lynch and his colleagues such as Senator Carrick were talking it all up for 2 1/2 years prior to the last election. But by 30 July this year one of the big investors in development projects in Australia, the Australian Mutual Provident Society, thought it was about time to tell people of the real situation. The AMP Society's manager of share and resource investment said that for the most part the resources boom had been energy related and was saturated as far as that company was concerned. By 3 August this year the Melbourne Age, after talking to organisations in Europe, warned that Australians, to use its own words, had been 'conned'. By whom had they been conned? Whom were the people of Australia conned by, if the statements in the Age editorial were correct? I will tell honourable senators whom Australians have been conned by; they have been conned by Ministers in the Fraser Government. The Age editorial further stated:
. . . some of the projects which have been touted in Australia are duds. They are projects which are basic to the boom.
After taking out some of the double-counting and chopping off the already duds, the list-
That is, Lynch's list-
has been estimated at nearer $17,000 million worth.

So the estimated worth of these projects is $17 billion rather than the $50 billion cited by the Minister for Industry and Commerce on 2 June this year. The figure is nearer $17 billion than $50 billion. Some of the projects are duds. What will be the reputation of this country and this Government if that sort of material, published in the Melbourne Age-I suggest it is a reputable newspaper-is published in foreign newspapers as well? Will the Australian resources boom be seen in the same way as the Australian meat industry where American comedians make a lot of money out of telling jokes about our meat export industry-for example, hopping of the stage like a kangaroo having eaten Australian beef. Those sorts of things are happening. Americans are making money out of that and laughing at us now. Will the same sort of thing happen in respect of the resources boom? Have we not developed since the time when emancipated convicts went back to the United Kingdom and sold gold bricks to the Poms? Have we not, as a nation, improved since then? The answer to that question must be no if Government Ministers are to persist in this sort of approach-talking things up prior to an election and letting them down afterwards.

The editorial in the Age is of course right. The wild talk of a $33 billion boom in resources development-the hard figure that Sir Phillip Lynch used, as distinct from the $50 billion that he mentioned a couple of months ago-is now coming to be seen for what it is, talk designed simply for last year's election. The Government, the editorial says, fine tunes the economy. It certainly fine tunes it before an election and then tunes it down afterwards. That is what has been happening in this case. The point that I wish to make again and again is that, in a sense, the reputation of everyone in this Parliament is at stake. Honourable senators on this side of the chamber have had to come here for two years and suggest by implication that the resources boom was being talked up, that perhaps we were going a little overboard about it all, yet be accused, to use Senator Carrick's words today, of being Jeremiahs, Hanrahans and Jonahs, people who were not really concerned about Australian development. We have been accused of that for two years, but listen to what Mr Anthony, the Minister for Trade and Resources, had to say on the subject only a day or two ago. Suddenly Mr Anthony, who is a fair hand at talking up the resources boom himself, decided to come clean; he began to play it down. He said that references to a boom were unfortunate. My God, they are unfortunate for many people who invested their hopes and aspirations in the boom, not to mention people who bought Rundle shares. Mr Anthony stated:
It is a convenient catch cry, but one with too many implications of speculation and uncontrolled growth and the unspoken implication of an ultimate bust.

So much for Mr Anthony's faith in the Government's capacity to manage such a boom if it should in fact arrive. He described it as a convenient catch cry. It was indeed a very convenient catch cry of the Fraser Government before the last election. It is a very inconvenient one now but there are still two and a half years to go before the next election. The statement of the Minister for Trade and Resources is breathtakingly cynical. This Parliament ought to be concerned about breathtaking cynicism on the part of Ministers because we all have problems of credibility in the profession that we follow and will continue to have them if that sort of talk is to become the standard language of Australian politics. It is breathtakingly cynical on the part of a senior Minister, the Acting Prime Minister of a government which has so deliberately built up people's hopes. The back-pedalling has even affected Sir Phillip Lynch's Department of Industry and Commerce. The word is out in the Department that any day now it will pull back its estimate of the worth of resources development from $33 billion to $20 billion. To be fair to the Department, it had mildly qualified its estimates in the past, but those qualifications were ignored by its Minister.

The Department of Trade and Resources, following a separate study of the situation, has indicated that the level of investment will be between $16 billion and $22 billion. The rubbery figures have finally been exposed, but not before many fingers have been burnt. An important case in point was that of the Rundle project-whatever may be said about it by way of denial and qualification. That project was talked up but now has been brought into a more realistic focus. Honourable senators on this side of the chamber wish Rundle well, as they do every resources project, but we do not encourage a process involving totally phoney exercises such as have been engaged in by this Government. It is no comfort to see our position confirmed. The damage done by the wilfulness and stupidity of Ministers is not to be brushed aside. If there is already in the community a perception that politicians and governments cannot be trusted, this episode will further entrench it. It will be to no avail, on this occasion for Senator Carrick to quote a publication of the New South Wales Government concerning its expectations of resource development in New South Wales. I see that he has it ready in his armoury of slanging material--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us why not? Are they rubbery figures?

—It is just possible that they are as bad as yours are. If Senator Carrick will study the New South Wales figures he will find that they are a little better documented than any of his, or any of the figures produced by Sir Phillip Lynch, ever were. If a State government may not acknowledge the overwhelming knowledge of a Federal government in respect of these matters then who should-the people of Australia?
—Are they wrong figures?

—I am not saying that. I am saying that, on the admission of the honourable senator's Government, his own Acting Prime Minister, his figures were wrong, were lies. That fact cannot be avoided in debating the matter in this Parliament. If the honourable senator wishes to reduce Australian politics to the lowest common demoninator he will, I suppose, answer the allegation by saying: 'We were wrong. We were cynical. We misled the Australian people but the New South Wales Labor Government is doing it too'. Such an argument represents the lowest common denominator in political discourse. It holds that anything is justified as long as one's opponents do it in one way or another.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us try to salvage something from the resources boom management issue. Such resources developments as will occur must still be subject to measures which will ensure that they will not warp the Australian economy. We allege that the Government has done very little to prepare for the pressures that inevitably will flow from the development of our mineral resources. Already there are pressures on exporters, especially farmers, because of an appreciation of the exchange rate. Economists have predicted that farmers could lose $100m a year, mostly because of appreciation of the dollar. Not even job maximisation will result from the boom. Firstly, there is a lack of planning to minimise disruption. Secondly, there is excessive foreign ownership and control. Thirdly, there are inadequate efforts to involve local manufacturers in supplying equipment for resources development. There is a totally supine attitude about the importation of foreign technology and capital. No conditions are applied in relation to technological transfer. Fourthly, an excessively restrictive monetary policy is hampering efforts to raise capital. Fifthly, there are chronic shortages of skills, a fact which has been talked about for years in this place, but about which very little has been done. Sixthly, there has been inadequate investment in social infrastructure.

I have drawn attention previously to the plight of communities, such as Gladstone, which are at the heart of resources development, for example, to the rapid increase in the number of families living in caravans. Some 300,000 Australian families, or more than twice the population of Canberra, are living in caravans. The position will not be helped by the recent introduction of sales tax on building materials, which can only force even higher the cost of housing. The supply of other infrastructure has also been notoriously slow. It took the workers of Gladstone, by banning future developments in that town, to force any concessions from the Queensland Government. I have previously described Gladstone as one of the dark satanic mills of Australia. Any Federal government makes a lot of money from what happens in Gladstone, but nothing has been done in the way of infrastructure developments there.

TALK.START.PARA: —They just got $50m.

—That came from the Queensland Government. The people of Gladstone have had no concessions at all from the Commonwealth Government in regard to infrastructure development. Again, the penetration of foreign capital into resources development is already alarming. Sir Gordon Jackson expressed only the other day his alarm about some aspects of that penetration. Vast profits already are flowing overseas because there is no control over foreign capital. To make matters worse foreign firms more often than not buy their heavy equipment overseas, thus denying our manufacturing sector a chance to participate as fully as it might. That is an important consideration especially, as I have mentioned, in a State such as Victoria, which relies heavily on manufacturing and has relatively little in the way of mineral resources. The flow of foreign capital has increased from $6 billion last year to an estimated $7 billion this year. These are all problems on which there has been insufficient guidance from Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We should acknowledge that the development of resources gives us opportunities to increase economic growth in a planned, steady way and to improve living standards and employment, but it has to be properly managed. We should encourage local participation, prepare economic and social plans, monitor demand for resource exports and, in my view, introduce a resource rental tax. We should bring order into the range of projects so that States are not wastefully bidding against each other for funds to develop specific projects. These are other considerations but they all require a serious, planned, thoughtful beginning, not empty rhetoric. We have already been promised-and seen the promise disappear-an export-led recovery, an investment-led recovery, and a consumer-led recovery. If there is to be resource-boom recovery, let it proceed with proper planning, realistic costing, and honesty from government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Virtually the whole, in fact some 15-odd minutes, of the 20 minutes of Senator Button's speech on this subject has been directed towards one thing-attempting to demolish the figure of some $33 billion put out by Sir Phillip Lynch as a reasonable forecast of what would be in the chute throughout Australia for the development of Australian resources. Indeed, as I recall it, the whole attack was that the figures were wrong, that we were led astray, that the figures were rubbery, and that the Australian people were being misled. Senator Button did not quite calculate what I was going to quote from. I was going to quote from the information source of his own Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, the Premier of New South Wales. I was also going to quote from a much more up to date document.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button, anticipating that I might use these figures, said that if I used the figures honourable senators should keep in mind that Mr Wran might be wrong, that he could have been misled by the Federal Government. We have the situation of a Premier who is going to the people in a few weeks saying things-I will quote those things-that the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Button) says people should not take any notice of because all the Premier's stuff on resources in terms of quantum and direction may be based on misleading information. I will quote from a document which is the text of a speech of His Excellency, the Governor of New South Wales. That speech was made on the 12th of this month, a handful of days ago. Let us not forget that the crux, the whole thrust, of Senator Button's argument is that the figure of $33 billion for the whole of Australia is enormously distorted and enormously wrong. What does the Federal President of the Labor Party, the Premier of New South Wales, say through the mouth of the Government of New South Wales? Only a handful of days ago he said:
Development projects valued at over $20,000 million are planned during the next five years. There will be major expansion in the mining, aluminium and steel industries.

The whole of the speech of the Governor of New South Wales, written and prepared by the Premier, the Federal President of the Labor Party, is based on the prediction that in New South Wales there will be expansion of the order of more than $20 billion. Of course, Senator Button was quite right in thinking that I would bring into the Senate the publication concerning development projects in New South Wales, signed by the responsible Minister of the New South Wales Government, listing all the items which the New South Wales Government says will add up to this amount of money. Let those who speak afterwards say what items they would strike out as rubbery, et cetera. The Government of New South Wales stated:
As at January 1981 the total value of projects in New South Wales announced, or planned for commencement, and currently under way, was of the order of $23,000 million.

On the basis of $23 billion for the population of New South Wales, the projection for the whole of Australia would be of the order of $80 billion to $85 billion. Where does that put Sir Phillip Lynch's projection? It makes it very discreetly low, modest in its thrust. I again ask: Does Senator Button say that this publication of the New South Wales Government, listing line after line after line of projects which add up to $23 billion, is wrong? Of course, he says that most of this money will be spent overseas, But the New South Wales Government says that most of it will be spent in industries in New South Wales for purchases of goods and services. Is the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party wrong in claiming that? Is this the greatest deception on earth? Is the Premier of New South Wales going to the people in the next few weeks telling them what Senator Button now says is a tissue of untruths?

Senator Button cannot have it both ways. He attacks the situation and says that the resources development will not create employment. In fact it has already created employment. I will quote what the Federal President of the Labor Party says is going to happen to employment opportunities. Incidentally, one would not believe that these kinds of statements came from a Labor leader. The New South Wales Government states:
Despite continuing problems on the world economic scene, there is cause for an optimistic view of the future for Australia, . . .
Australia can look forward to a brighter 1981 than most major industrialised countries in the West, according to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development . . .
Australia's gross domestic product growth is expected by the OECD to accelerate from 2.5 per cent in 1980 to around 4 per cent in 1981.
We know now that that figure is being put higher. The New South Wales Government continues:
Australia's rate of inflation of 10.2 per cent in the twelve months to September 1980, remained below that of the U.S.A. . . .

So the document continues. In that statement the Labor Premier cast down every one of the arguments put up by Senator Button. Senator Button implies quite clearly that Mr Wran is wrong and is hoodwinking the people of New South Wales.
I turn to the subject of employment because, in the words of Senator Button, that was supposed to be a 'con job'. However, Mr Wran's Government states:
Employment opportunities expected to be created in relation to projects in the committed and final feasibility stages, where such information is available, total approximately 50,000 jobs.
I repeat the words 'in the committed and final feasibility stages . . . 50,000 jobs'. That relates to direct employment. The statement continues:
Most of the employment opportunities reported are expected to occur between 1981 and 1985.
Mr Wran's Government continues:
These data relate to direct employment only and do not include the increased indirect employment likely to be generated in supplier industries . . .
If Senator Button wants a multiplier, that is of the order of four times. The economists generally agree on that. Apart from the 50,000 jobs in New South Wales, Mr Wran's Government makes this claim:
In addition, at least 22,000 jobs are represented by major projects which are in preliminary study or possible stages.
Thus the employment details that are available are likely to considerably understate the potential employment opportunities which will arise . . .

There Mr Wran's Government was talking of the order of something like 100,000 new jobs. That figure is far away in excess of Sir Phillip Lynch's figure. He was talking about expenditure in Australia and not overseas. He was talking about the development of Australia and of New South Wales. Every word in that document and in the Governor's speech is in refutation of what Senator Button has said today.

On the subject of 'con jobs', how can anyone come here and pin virtually the whole of his speech around an attempt to rubbish a figure of $33 billion for Australia when in fact the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party is pinning his flag to $23 billion for 37 per cent of Australia, that is, New South Wales. His whole argument falls down in a flight of words. We have a document stating that everything Senator Button says is wrong. List after list of items of undertakings that are going ahead is published in this speech and they are the ones upon which the New South Wales Government bases its claim.

So let us put the thing in perspective. Here is a government that came to office six years ago when inflation was running at 17 per cent and heading through the roof; when Australia was being costed out of world markets and was in the top quarter of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development high inflation countries; and when Australia was losing jobs. In one action by the Whitlam Government 130,000 people were wiped out of the manufacturing industry. That was the result of the decision to cut tariffs across the board by 25 per cent. The situation is that last year inflation dropped by 2 per cent to 8.8 per cent, which is well below the OECD average. Real employment-and, happily, real employment amongst the young-was on the up and up.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you call unemployed? What is real employment?

—Perhaps the Senate would like to have the comments of the Premier of New South Wales about what is happening to real employment. The Premier of New South Wales says that real employment is rising and that in fact there has been a decline of 35 per cent in youth unemployment in his State. This is the pattern throughout Australia. Members of the Opposition cannot have it both ways. They cannot come in here on some kind of a device and say they are going to demolish this figure without having to face up to what is happening in New South Wales and elsewhere in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me put this matter in perspective. The fact is that the world outside Australia is in the grip of a massive energy hunger brought about by the oil prices set by the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries and the fact that the world is running out of oil. In putting this in perspective we must remember that today the world is consuming oil at twice the rate it is finding it and it will run out of it. In fact, since 1973, when there was a quadrupling of world oil prices, the world has been shrinking in its ability to trade and buy anything except oil. World inflation has been forced up by some 9 per cent as a result of oil prices. The world is facing a situation in which many countries are energy hungry. They have not got alternatives and they are turning to countries like Australia for help. If one wanted to talk about resources management one would have thought that the Labor Party would have acknowledged first of all that we have a responsibility to the people outside Australia, to the world. We have a responsibility to get them energy-to get our coal on the sea, to get our natural gas on the sea and to get them uranium so that they can generate electric power, so that they can stay alive and keep up their living standards. Not a word about that came from the Opposition. What did we hear in the whole of the 20-minute speech from the Opposition? We heard some nonsense, which is now completely demolished by the facts. We heard nonsense about figures.

The fact is that the Labor Party ignores the world outside. It ignores the fact that we have a responsibility to get our coal mines going, to get our electric power stations going, to find the natural gas, to find the oil, to get the bauxite, alumina and iron ore on the sea, to get it overseas to people whose living standards will fall unless we in Australia help. Very few countries have the capacity to reach out and lend a helping hand. There is sneering and denigration instead of great encouragement. If the Labor Party wanted people overseas to maintain healthy living standards and wanted the developing countries not to collapse politically and economically, its supporters would have been saying: 'Let us get on the sea and away more and more of our help to these people, either our raw energy or our processed materials, because that is the way in which we can have in this world people who are not starving.'

Look at what the International Energy Agency has said. It was said unanimously by 21 nations. It said that there is no way in which energy can be developed and living standards can be maintained in this world unless nuclear power is developed as one of the most significant of the energy sources. The Agency went on to say that unless this happens people will starve, people's living standards will fall and people will freeze because of an inability to provide energy. What has happened? There has been the greatest propaganda campaign aimed at denying uranium to the peacetime uses of the world. This is creating an atmosphere of pollution. Those behind this campaign know in their hearts, as the International Energy Agency knows, that if we go on burning coal at the kind of rate that is being talked about we will create health hazards in the world. We will create an effect on the atmosphere which is irreversible. We will create acid rain.

Here we have supporters of the alternative government getting up on their feet in this place, ignoring the world outside, ignoring the terrible things that are likely to happen to other countries unless we get this resource development going. They attempted a smart trick but failed on the figures.

Let us talk about this because this Government of ours is keen that the world outside should be stable. It is keen that we should be helping countries with coal, gas and uranium. We want to get these things on the move and we are getting them on the move. This Government of ours and the member nations of the International Energy Agency want Australia to get its steaming coal exports up from about 6 million tonnes at this moment to 120 million or 130 million tonnes in a decade's time. What is said? Is Mr Wran wrong? Is all this development a hoax? He said that more than 20 coal mining projects are under consideration which will lead to the establishment of new mines to produce coal for both local and overseas requirements. He said that major coal resource development at Saxonvale and at Drayton will involve capital investment of $375m and further development in the Gunnedah-Boggabri coal region will involve expenditure of almost $150m. Are they rubbery, shonky figures? If they are not, you know, the Senate will know the case against Senator Button has been proved. Step by step, these projects were itemised throughout the Governor's speech.

It is said that we have done nothing about infrastructure. My goodness, we brought in the infrastructure financing in 1978. We provided something like $4.5 billion in extra loan funds so that we in Australia could get on with the building of power stations and all these other things. Mr Wran says-and I somewhat doubt it-that New South Wales will have a sufficiency in electric power from the projects in that State. The fact of the matter is that we have provided the infrastructure. The fact of the matter is that we took over an education system in which the technical and further education skills had been downgraded and the white collar jobs upgraded. We have pumped more and more money into the technical and further education field to lift the skills of apprentices and others to offset what was a serious drain. We have brought in the Foreign Investment Review Board regulations. The fact of the matter is that we are insisting upon Australian equity of at least 50 per cent-and we are getting it-in investment projects in this country.

Here we are with a government that can say these things at the end of a Budget year at the start of which the Labor Party said some 12 months ago: 'You have brought down this Budget. It is a horror Budget. It will create more unemployment and more inflation. There will be no growth and no development'. I remind Labor Party supporters of those things because today they are saying the same things.
