SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Carrick, was getting so excited a few minutes ago that I thought he was going to start talking up Rundle shares again. I will not get involved in a long disputation about the figures which he presented. A report prepared by Mr Lynch's Department, which has been suppressed by John Stone for his own political reasons, downgrades the figure of $33 billion to something below $25 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week a Budget was presented in which the Government itself forecast that in this financial year inflation would go up, unemployment would go up, interest rates would remain at record levels or go higher, taxes which are already at record levels would go higher, and economic growth would come down. There could be no more telling indictment of the Government's failure to manage the so-called resources boom than that self-confessed failure. If higher interest rates, higher inflation, higher taxes, higher unemployment and lower economic growth equal economic success, may God protect us from failure, because Malcolm Fraser obviously cannot.

After five years of rhetorical and false forecasts, it is correct that last year there was substantial economic growth. That growth, for the only year since Mr Fraser became Prime Minister, was above the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average and was high enough to make a small dent on the previously continuously rising level of unemployment. Growth was induced chiefly by a substantial increase in real terms in consumer demand and by a 20 per cent increase in real terms in investment expenditure-much of it but by no means all, it is correct, was associated with resources investment.

In this period interest rates rocketed, increasing to all time record levels. There were several reasons for that. First, and possibly most importantly, is the psychological factor-the fact that the financial market no longer believes anything the Government says. The financial market was fed so much false information during 1977 and 1978, the highlight of which was the Prime Minister's unqualified guarantee that interest rates would fall by 2 per cent, that it no longer believes anything the Government says about interest rates. Rising interest rate expectations are induced by past attempts by the Government to deceive the financial market. Interest rates were pushed up also by a very large surge in private investment and by foreign capital inflow. I will say a bit more about that later.

The Government does not acknowledge any of those matters. Obviously it will not acknowledge that its own past attempts to deceive the money market are a significant factor-perhaps the prime factor-in record and rising interest rates. The Government does not admit the crucial role of the vast increase in private investment in forcing up interest rates. Instead it spreads the furphy that the record interest rates have been caused by the rapacious borrowing demands of the public sector. In that line the Government is assisted by the Stone Age ideologues in the Treasury who posture as economic scientists. The plain fact is that the total public sector borrowing requirement has fallen continuously from 6 per cent of gross domestic product in 1977-78 to 3.2 per cent in 1980-81. Government policy seeks to kill off public sector investment, both directly and indirectly, by squeezing the States. It will, at the margin, kill off private investment with record interest rates. It is true-to a substantial degree it was the case in 1980-that private investment was an engine, though not the sole engine, of economic growth. However, it does not follow automatically that all private investment is desirable. The opportunity cost of some private investment exceeds its benefit. In other words, growth would be higher if some forms of investment were forgone, thereby freeing resources for other forms of investment. I stress that I am not making value judgments about the final product; I am simply referring to the effect on economic growth as it is recorded, without passing value judgments about whether what is recorded as economic growth is necessarily socially desirable or whether that proportion of output which is included in gross domestic product is necessarily socially desirable.

We have seen some outstanding examples of private investment which would have been better forgone. The most outstanding example-it is happening now and it will happen in the future-is the film industry where tax subsidies of up to 120 per cent of the cost of making a film are available. Tax subsidies of up to 105 per cent of the investment are available for water storage and reticulation projects, and for emergency fuel storage there are tax concessions which will cost revenue more than it would have cost to buy larger tanks to store an equivalent amount of fuel. A 100 per cent deduction applies to the fencing of land which is liable to erosion. No farm land in the world is not liable to erosion or, in fact, is not eroding, so all fences on agricultural land are eligible for immediate write-off. All of those things, all of those tax rorts, have been introduced by this Government in the last 15 months. I mention also the pre-election bribe of an accelerated 20 per cent depreciation allowance for investment in agricultural machinery when all the empirical evidence showed that farmers already had a propensity to overinvest in plant and capital equipment. Of course, we have also the notorious 20 per cent investment allowance, which was first introduced in 1976 as a 40 per cent investment allowance. That was to have led to an investment-led recovery.

If investment demands are placing unacceptable pressure on interest rates and physical resources, the first response from any rational government should be to remove such artificial stimuli to investment which, in addition, misallocate investment resources. Predictably, the Fraser Government did the opposite. As recently as three months ago it was passing through this Parliament the most outrageous of its investment stimuli-the 120 per cent subsidy for investment in film making. The Prime Minister seems to believe that if it is a cost to revenue through the tax system it is not actually the same as governments providing money. That is related to some of his psychological hang ups. Last weekend a token reference was belatedly sent off to the Industries Assistance Commission for it to look at some of these matters. I say 'token' advisedly because one does not need either an IAC or six months to discover that all of the Prime Minister's off-the-top-of-the-head tax rorts and election bribes which have passed through this Parliament in the last 15 months ought to be scrapped if there is excessive pressure on available investment resources. The Government's answer to what it perceives to be the problem is to kill off investment demand across the board with rising interest rates.

Of course, assorted members of this Government have a view of rising interest rates which is different from that of most people. When the Prime Minister bought a house in Canberra in 1974 he had enough cash to make it a straight cash transaction. When the Prime Minister's wife needed $50,000 for the family farming business, it was obtained from the Victorian Government at an interest rate of 4 per cent. When Sinclair Pastoral Co. Pty Ltd had a liquidity problem, it received a $400,000 cash transfusion from a funeral company. When someone found out and complained about it, the cash transfusion was converted into a loan at a fixed 10 per cent rate of interest. Lesser Government clients have been looked after to a lesser extent. I asked Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle last week whether a farmer in a drought-affected area who might have assets worth $10m could get government money at 4.5 per cent interest and bank overdraft money at 10.5 per cent interest, whilst people with negligible assets who had a housing loan had to pay 12.5 per cent to a bank and more than that to anyone else. The answer to those questions, of course, is yes. People in this Government, the clique of wealthy and millionaire graziers who dominate this country, have a perception of high and rising interest rates very different from that of the millions of ordinary Australians that they govern.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting to hear Senator Walsh speak on this matter. I assume that one or two people outside this place were still listening to Senator Walsh at the end of his remarks. The subject matter of debate is:

SPEECH.PARA: The management of resources development by the Federal Government.

I have noticed in the first two weeks of this session that Senator Walsh has not spoken in this place as often as usual. I was hoping he would have used that time to study this matter. Unfortunately, the performance he has just given demonstrated a totally negative approach to the subject to which he referred; also he did not even talk about the subject under review. I can forgive him his usual diatribe of negative remarks but I cannot forgive him for being negative about a matter that has nothing to do with the subject at hand.

There is no doubt in the minds of most people that the resources boom is good for Australia. It certainly creates short term problems and it is the Government's job to manage those problems. The Australian Labor Party would have people believe that the resources boom is bad for Australia. What do the members of the Labor Party want? What are they saying? How do they explain the situation to, for instance, potential employees? How do they explain it to graduates or to tradesmen, or to the many qualified people in the community who are working well below their qualifications? Lastly, how do they explain it to the unemployed? The resources boom has the ultimate potential-it is already demonstrating that potential-to solve many of our problems in Australia in regard to all sorts of matters, but particularly employment.

The economic background of resources development is that the Commonwealth Government has established a policy whereby the benefits will be good for all Australians. I say that they will be good because there has been-I guess the Press is partly to blame for this-a rather false expectation in the minds of many people. They believe we are having a boom. I do not like using that word because it conjures up expectations, and those expectations are not being realised. There is no doubt in my mind that eventually they will be realised but it will take some time and the development needs to be managed very carefully. There is no doubt that the economic climate is encouraging. Investment in Australia is at an unprecedented level. The only fear in the minds of those people contemplating development in Australia is that the Labor Party will be returned to government. They can remember what went wrong. They hear the claims of the Labor Party that it will not support policies that have been adopted by this Government. Not just in the area of uranium development but in many other areas as well, commitments made by this Government which encouraged enormous development will not be supported by a future Labor government. What sort of economic encouragement will that give to a potential investor in Australia?

The fact that there is a growth is not denied. In the first half of 1980 there was an increase of about $5 billion in resource development expenditure. In the first half of 1981 the figure rose to $6.8 billion. Those are actual figures. From 1975-76 to 1979-80 the increase in exports was 87.9 per cent. In iron ores, for instance, for which my State has the prime role, from 1975-76 to 1978-79-these are the latest figures available-the increase was 39.6 per cent; for coal the increase was 63.7 per cent, for aluminium and alumina the increase was 122.7 per cent, and for lead and zinc it was 211.1 per cent. There is no doubt that the development is taking place and that the community is benefiting from it.

With regard to foreign investment, I direct the attention of the Senate to a paper written by Messrs Gallagher, McColl, Copeland and McDonald on the subject of the relevance of foreign investment in resource development. The title of the paper is 'National Economic Benefits of the Gladstone Aluminium Smelter'. One of their conclusions was that increases in Australian equity in that project would produce a relatively small increase in the net present value of the project to Australia. How does that statement stand up in the face of repeated claims by the Australian Labor Party that it is imperative that resource development be undertaken by Australians; not necessarily solely, but that they should have a very large investment in the project. The Labor Party would sooner see a project stopped than have a major foreign equity in that resource. But the comment I have just mentioned from that paper demonstrates that the return to the Australian community depends very slightly on the equity arrangements. Of course, that is, because the dividend that is earned is only a small percentage of the value that is earned from that investment.

The three broad aims of our foreign investment policy in Australia are to raise the level of real resources available to Australians, to bring new management skills and technology to Australia and to open new markets and create new employment opportunities. The Government's foreign investment policy welcomes foreign investment. It not only increases the resources available in the economy but also it can increase Australia's access to up to date technology and managerial skills and open up new market opportunities. I think the foreign investment policy is well understood by Australians. The aim is to have at least a 50 per cent equity in resource development projects in Australia. If that cannot be obtained in the short term, the Foreign Investment Review Board is empowered to allow that project to commence on the undertaking and assurance that the Australian equity will be at least 50 per cent in a very short time. As we know, the Labor Party has indicated time and again that it would rather see no development than have that sort of policy adopted.

There has been a great deal of criticism of the Government and of the Taxation Office for the Government's taxation policy. The most recent Budget has some strong things to say about taxation. It has changed significantly the rate of taxation that will be reaped from these resources development projects. I refer in particular to the high wages that are paid to employees, which of course attract a higher level of tax. I refer also to the fact that the Government has increased the total amount that it will receive from the resource development industries.

With regard to employment, as I said before there are large numbers of people who are looking to the resource development industries for their future. They are well advised to do so. The amount of effort that is going into this area is quite exciting. There has been a general criticism that the resource development industries will push up the cost of labour to unacceptably high figures and make it more difficult for competing industries or other industries in the community to compete. But it is my belief that there is a large pool of labour in the community that is working at well below its training or capacity. Many people have jobs at the moment which do not exercise their full capacity. They will be attracted to these industries, but not necessarily away from the other competing resource development industries.

I believe that the Government may have made a slight mistake in its assessment of the future employment needs of the resource development industries in Australia. I would recommend that another survey be done, because I do not think the available information is sufficient. A larger group of people in the community is available for employment in the resource development industry than has been claimed.

Touching on other areas of resource development, the Government's crude oil pricing policy has been attacked very strongly by our critics. I point out that in the year 1981-82 the excise levy revenues are estimated to be $3,357m-about 72 per cent of the crude oil revenues before tax and royalties. In the light of these figures it is crazy to claim that we are not collecting sufficient tax from these industries. It is estimated that $83m will accrue from the liquefied petroleum gas industry. The Bass Strait oil producers pay royalties at rates of up to 12 1/2 per cent on the well-head value of petroleum products. It is estimated that in the year 1981-82 Bass Strait will provide revenue of $215m. That is to be shared, of course, between the State and Commonwealth governments. Esso alone will provide $208m in taxation. It is expected that overall government take in 1981-82 will result in aggregate government revenues of some $4 billion from petroleum products.

The Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, which I have the honour to chair, is completing an inquiry into the aluminium industry. Although I do not like speaking for the other members of my committee, because we have not yet brought down our report, speaking for myself and taking into account all the evidence we have received, I have come to the conclusion that the aluminium industry is good for Australia. It provides jobs and it is providing new jobs and investment opportunities for people within Australia as well as those overseas. In fact, I met many potential private investors who are attracted to that industry.

Whilst Senator Button spent a very short time talking about the problems in the resources industry in Gladstone, he failed to mention other areas where the development program is welcomed. I was told by senior local government people in Portland that they welcome the development there. In fact, they asked me why they could not have two smelters instead of one. That is an example of a good State Government supporting the initiatives taken by the Federal Government, solving in a sensible and rational way problems that can have a tremendous impact on a local community. These are some of the human problems that can be created. I congratulate the State governments for facing up to these problems, because this is one of the areas for which they are primarily responsible. I also congratulate my Government for the support it is giving the State governments in this important area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I rise to support the matter of public importance which is before the chamber this afternoon. The topic is the management of resources development by the Federal Government, and I think it is very necessary, when making a contribution to this debate, to keep in mind those terms of reference. The Senate is concerned, as a matter of public importance, that the management of resources development by the Federal Government be discussed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party is in favour of the accelerated resources development that is taking place within the Australian community. There is no doubt that the great reserves of minerals and energy resources, coupled with the skills, enterprise and sheer hard work of many Australians, will create such national wealth that many Australians ought to be able to share in an increased, more prosperous standard of living. We are concerned that the accelerated resources development being undertaken should be managed in such a way by the Government -the Federal Government, the national Government-that those benefits are distributed in a fair manner to all Australians, wherever they might reside. Nothing in the remarks of the Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Carrick, in any way allayed the concern expressed by the Labor Party in bringing forward this matter of public importance. No strategy was outlined which indicated that the national Government saw a need to co-ordinate the resource development taking place throughout Australia. There was certainly no indication of any sense of direction or management of the time, pace, and scale of the resource development. We have nothing to indicate that anything is going on in Australia other than a confused scramble, a competition between State governments to secure for each State community some major resource project or projects. So one has a competitive scramble for these resource developments which, without some national Government management, could well lead, and is leading, in the view of many, to the inability of the nation as a whole to secure for all Australians the sorts of benefits that should derive from those resource developments. I say that with some sorrow.

Senator Thomas referred to the work of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. It is a fact that in February this year I queried the top Federal bureaucrats who were giving evidence to the Committee as to whether there was some co-ordination between the Federal and State Ministers concerned with minerals and energy to secure a pace and strategy of development that would secure benefits for all Australians. In other words, I was not asking that a national blueprint be manufactured somewhere in Canberra, or that some unitary action be taken single mindedly by the national Minister. Keeping in mind the Federal structure and accepting the constitutional restraints that come from the Federal system, I asked whether any discussion had taken place between the Federal and State Ministers for minerals and energy on the growth of the aluminium industry, which is the prime example in the minds of all Australians of the sort of resources development which may be welcomed.

I asked Mr Monaghan, the Director of the National Energy Office, whether in the past three years any Ministers had met to undertake such a task of review and co-ordination. His reply was: 'I do not think so'. There we had a reply to the Senate Standing Committee that, even within the constraints of federalism, this Federal Government has made no attempt to manage the resources boom in a way which would ensure that benefits flowed to all Australians. Of course, this is recognised not only by the Labor Party but also by such excellent Australians as Mr Gordon Jackson, the General Manager of CSR Ltd. Only last weekend Mr Jackson said that a national concensus had to be developed to overcome the strains and adjustments of the resources boom. He further said that much of the responsibility for the concensus lay with Australian governments, and it was imperative that they collectively brought some clear sense of purpose and direction to the task of resource development, so that it might be socially beneficial.

That responsibility of governments, which should be initiated primarily by the national Government and by the Minister in this chamber, has not been undertaken, and there was no indication at all in the Minister's remarks that such a strategy would be undertaken. One can take many examples, both in the foreign investment field and in regard to employment opportunities, and those topics have been touched on by my colleagues.

Perhaps there is no matter of greater concern to those who might be listening to this broadcast than the question of the pricing of electricity to these great resource projects. Every consumer of electricity throughout Australia is asking whether the household or the small domestic trader or commercial concern is paying such a high tariff that the household or the small trading or commercial enterprise is indeed subsidising these great resource projects, particularly those in the aluminium industry. Many people are asking that question, and one would have thought that the Minister for National Development and Energy would share their concern and at least would be trying to compile the sort of information which would enable the Federal Government to ensure that the tariff policies of State governments were such that the major resource projects being undertaken were not subsidised by domestic or small trading or commercial enterprises.

What is the Federal Government's response in the face of this concern within the community? Is it putting itself in a position where it can know, be aware of, the tariffs being charged by electricity commissions to these great resource projects? Once again, in evidence before the Senate Committee it became very clear that not only was the Federal Government not formally demanding that such tariffs be placed before it, but also it was not even requesting that such tariffs be placed before it. The Minister for National Development and Energy is not even trying to find out the actual level of charges being levied by State electricity commissions on these great resource projects. That leads to many consequences, amongst them a possible diminution of tax revenue. If the Commissioner of Taxation does not know the true cost of the electricity input to these resource projects, then it becomes very difficult to assess whether the profit levels being proclaimed are, indeed, a true indication of the profitability of the enterprise. It also means that the Minister for National Development and Energy is in no position to say whether the coal or gas resources, whichever may be used for the generation of electricity, are being used in the best possible manner, or whether perhaps some coal resources ought to be reserved to enable the coal liquefaction plants of the future to overcome the shortage of transport fuels which is predicted for the turn of the century. It is quite clear that the Minister for National Development and Energy in the national Government is not even putting himself in a position to come to grips with the proper allocation of these resources within Australia.

Another matter of great concern in the community is the control of these national resources, these mineral and energy resources, by overseas investors. There would be no complaint on the part of any Australian if overseas capital were brought into Australia to bring to fruition some of these great projects which otherwise would not be undertaken at all. It is quite clear that at times not only are the technology and the managerial skills which can be brought from overseas essential to the development of these projects but also quite often the nature of the industry is such, as with the very highly integrated aluminium industry, that unless some participation on the part of foreign investors is obtained at, for example, the smelting stage, the development will just not be undertaken. So there are occasions on which the participation of foreign investors in the development of our resources projects is, indeed, welcome. The same applies to the proportion of investment.

But surely the Government can appreciate the concern in the Australian community which expresses itself in the fear that ordinary Australians are being squeezed out of the opportunities to share in the ownership of these projects. It is simply not good enough that great Australian companies such as Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd or CSR take their place in particular developments. It is not even good enough that the superannuation funds channel the compulsory savings of many millions of Australians into these projects by way of equity participation, although the fact that that is happening now is to be welcomed. Some sort of unit trust fund is needed whereby ordinary Australians can contribute their hundreds of dollars to this investment in Australia's resource projects so that more money will be returned to them as investors of the comparatively small savings which may have accumulated in their ordinary bank accounts. Some sort of resources development fund needs to be established so that small investors' funds can be mobilised.

This would not only increase Australian equity in some sort of abstractly desirable matter but also it would be politically very important as it would involve many millions of ordinary Australians in the development of these projects. There is no doubt that there is a feeling in the community that these projects are being undertaken by foreign investors in collusion with State governments whose allegiance appears to be more to an alliance with these international investors rather than with a concern for the social cohesion of Australia as a whole. It is really to that social cohesion as a whole that we look to the Federal Government, the national Government, the Government of all Australians, to ensure that the resources development undertaken is such that all Australians, wherever they live, will benefit.

As I have emphasised in my remarks, the Australian Labor Party welcomes resources development. It welcomes it as a way of increasing national wealth, of utilising our skills and enterprise and of using our work force. We are blessed with great minerals and energy resources. However, we are concerned to ensure that State governments do not, in a fragmented way, apparently secure benefits for their own State communities so that other parts of Australia and other Australians find themselves without any benefit from the increased standards of living that should flow from this resource development. The pace of this development, the call by this development on Australia's financial resources, can be controlled, monitored and co-ordinated only by the national Government. Only in that way will there be an increase in national living standards for all. That resource development planning needs the leadership of a national government.

It surprises me that so frequently the national Minister fails to acquire the information which would put him in a position of leadership. He hides behind constitutional veils and talks about the responsibilities of the States. As I have pointed out, he fails to use the federal forums available within which all Ministers for minerals and energy from throughout Australia could meet around a table and discuss the various projects which are in prospect. The management of the resources development projects throughout Australia ought to be undertaken by the national Government and the Australian Labor Party wishes to ensure that it takes place. For that reason it makes no apology for the fact that about every four or five months this matter becomes a matter of public importance within this chamber. It is our intention to press the point until there is forthcoming from the national Government, as Mr Gordon Jackson of CSR has requested, a true recognition of its responsibilities in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very pleased to hear the previous speaker say that the Australian Labor Party is not against resources development. He also said that we have to have this debate every three or four months because the ALP is so concerned at the way things are going. I suggest that when we are pressed for time, if members of the Opposition feel a burning urge to have this debate once again, we could incorporate all our previous speeches and then get on with the business of the Senate. Nonetheless this matter is before us again today. I think we debated it on 25 February and maybe some of the same speakers took part then. I was very pleased to hear Senator Tate say-I hope that he speaks for the total membership of the ALP-that members of the Opposition are not against resource development and that they mainly have hassles with the way it is going. However, I am not quite sure whether he would be speaking for all ALP members.

SPEECH.PARA: Resources development in Australia really started to get underway, I suppose, in the 1960s when we were developing resources to provide raw materials for other countries. Until then we had coal mines, iron ore mines and other industries for our own use. It was really in the 1960s when the world became desperate for supplies of coking coal that the development of our resources started to take off. It happened at a fortuitous time. Honourable senators will remember that during the 1960s we saw a major downturn in wool prices and, at the same time, a rather disastrous drought which had a devastating effect on the primary industries in Australia.

I recall that it particularly affected my own State of Queensland. At that time I was working in the railways and was based in Cloncurry. I saw both the devastation of the drought and the effect that that downturn in wool prices was having on many people who, until that time, had been making a good living on the land. Fortunately the resources boom started to take off. We were able to provide employment for many young people who had to leave the land at that time. It was a tragedy that those young people had to leave, although we could not do anything at that stage, because now we are recognising the fact that we have lost a generation of expertise in working the land and running the beef and sheep industries. However, that is a little aside.

Fortunately, as I have said, the resources boom started to take off and we provided employment for those young people, particularly in the coal mining industries. The resources boom developed further in the 1970s when we had another downturn-this time in the beef industry. Once again it provided employment. Not only did it provide that very necessary employment at that stage but also it provided a very necessary boost to decentralisation. My State is one of the most decentralised States in Australia. We find that without such developments as these mining projects-and this applies not only to people in Queensland but also to people in the other States-people naturally seem to go towards the capital cities and it is not healthy for any country to have that happen. So the development of our resources has provided a very necessary boost to decentralisation. Of course, even before the boom took off there was an element of decentralisation in early mining communities such as Broken Hill, Mount Isa and Mary Kathleen. But the resources boom has added impetus to the movement of people to those areas and this is to the great benefit of our country.

Our resources are no good either to ourselves or to nations which are in need of those resources if they are left in the ground. I think there would be agreement on both sides of the chamber on that fact. But it is not just a matter of digging resources out of the ground and selling them off. If we did this we could very soon become a gravel pit of the world. In simplistic terms, we should not dig up a bit more gravel and sell it if we need money to buy something. It is very essential that Australians share in the returns from our resources. Of course, that has been the Federal Government's attitude right down the line. We have been criticised for taking that attitude.

I should mention the use of our export controls. The Federal Government, through its intelligence, became aware of the fact that we were not receiving what would be generally recognised as a fair price for our product. Because we took a stand we ran into problems with some of our colleagues in the States. I can completely understand their attitudes. They felt there was a Big Brother attitude and that we were stifling their development. It is quite right that they keep a watchful eye on what we do. Our intelligence was to the effect that some of the buyers were acting as a cartel. They were playing one mining company off against another and as a result we were not actually receiving what would be generally considered to be a fair price. So the Commonwealth Government, in spite of the criticism it received from those who are normally friendly towards it, stepped in and used its export controls to make sure that Australian companies received a fair price. This sort of action has to be of overall benefit to the Australian community.

Another principle which the Government instituted and which has caused concern and criticism concerns Australian equity. We have a general policy that in any mining venture that is getting off the ground there should be about 50 per cent Australian equity and about 50 per cent Australian voting strength on the board. The exception is uranium investment, where a 75 per cent equity and control is required. Of course, the implementation of this policy has to be very finely balanced. We know quite well that there is not enough money in all Australia to undertake the vast mining developments that have taken place over the last few years. So the Federal Government has had to take the balanced view that although we need sufficient foreign investment the Australian people themselves should be able to partake in the resources development. To its credit, the Federal Government has been pretty flexible on this matter-some people would say too flexible and others would say not flexible enough. This argument cannot be settled to everyone's satisfaction. But I make the point that our Australian equity policy has been implemented to enable Australians to partake in the development of our resources.

The resources boom has also had an effect, of course, in the employment area. I have mentioned the problems that we would have faced as a result of people leaving the pastoral industries. However, it must be recognised that a generally accepted rule of thumb is that for every person employed in a mining industry four persons are employed in ancillary industries which are not necessarily at the mine site. So once again the resource development provides a measure of decentralisation. In my own State ancillary industries have sprung up at Rockhampton, Mackay and Gladstone to service the mine-fields of central Queensland. Also, some work is being undertaken at Bowen. So the development of resources has a multiplier effect. This development has helped the employment situation. Indeed, since we came to power we have been putting more and more people into the work force almost continually year by year. We should not understimate the amount of company tax that has gone into our Federal coffers or the income tax that is paid by the people who are employed in the mining industry and the ancillary industries. Royalties, rail freights and levies have all contributed to Consolidated Revenue and have thus had an effect across a broad spectrum of Australian development, social welfare, defence and all the rest of it.

I would like to introduce a note of caution. I think we have to be a little careful. We are currently at the stage where it is almost a battle between the States and the Commonwealth to see who can get the most out of mining companies. I think in fairness it must be said that mining companies are not looking too kindly at that development. There is a need for both the Federal and State governments to maintain some liaison in this matter, to see that royalties, rail freights and levies do not prevent development from going ahead. Of course, over and above all this, Mr Hayden said in a speech yesterday that he would introduce a resource rental tax. Of course, if anything would have a stifling effect on development I think that measure certainly would.

We have had a massive degree of infrastructure development. Technology has been introduced. We did not have such things as massive drag lines in Australia until our resources boom got going. We can now build this equipment ourselves, albeit under sub-contract. But Australian workmanship is going 100 per cent into drag line construction. We were able to introduce the locotrol system into the industry in which I was previously engaged-the railway industry. I do not think this system operated at that time in any other country. The system, which was introduced on the line with which I was concerned, involves putting three diesels at the head of a train. Three more diesels which are unattended and operated by a driver in the lead diesel are put in the middle of the train. This system enables power and braking to be distributed more evenly throughout the train. It is to the credit of the railwaymen with whom I worked at that time that this innovative system was introduced without any hitches. The men who operate those trains grasped the significance of the equipment. Although we had no one to teach us how to use this completely new development we were able to handle and operate it. We were told what to expect. Indeed, we modified what we were told so that the equipment worked very effectively. To the credit of my colleagues in the railway at that time the system was introduced and has worked well. So new technology has come along. We have complete new railway systems, which of course, have been of massive benefit. They have not cost taxpayers a cent but the capital costs have been paid by the mining companies and they in turn are being repaid by freight differentials. The upshot is that we will have a complete railway system including rolling stock and locomotives which will not be paid for by the taxpayer but which will be of great benefit to the State.

We have set up study groups, both international and interstate, to look at the processing of our raw materials. We have provided tax benefits and the investment allowance. Mr Hayden said that he would get rid of the investment allowance. Yet that allowance has helped companies to purchase machinery to process our raw materials instead of sending it somewhere else.

It is quite interesting to look at what has been espoused by certain members of the Australian Labor Party in this chamber in respect of uranium enrichment, that is, the processing of a raw material. We need a uranium processing capacity in Australia. It will provide us with another industry. It will provide us with expertise and know-how. As the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) said in his speech, we have to look more seriously at nuclear power. We cannot continue to burn fossil fuels. We are not quite sure of what the greenhouse effect will be. However, we know that ultimately our actions could have an effect on generations to come. We know that the unwarranted burning of too much fossil fuel could disadvantage the lifestyle of future generations of Australia and the world. We have to look very seriously at the nuclear power industry and, of course, at the processing and enrichment in Australia of that uranium.

I will briefly mention Gladstone. On a previous occasion and during his speech on this matter of public importance Senator Button mentioned all the problems associated with Gladstone. Nobody is denying the fact that there are problems at Gladstone. When I lived in Cloncurry I knew of problems at Mount Isa when it was fast developing. Such problems are the result of growing pains. The people of Gladstone are sick and tired of hearing what a bad place it is. They are particularly sick and tired of southern media representatives coming up, taking photos and going back and showing what an awful place Gladstone is. It is a very desirable place to live and there are many happy people living there. Mr Acting Deputy President, being a fellow Queenslander, I am sure you share that view. We get a little sick and tired of the wonderful town of Gladstone, albeit with growing pains, being used as an example.

DEBATE.TITLE: GOVERNMENT CLOTHING FACTORY, COBURG, AND ORDNANCE FACTORY, BENDIGO

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference to Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations: The Government's decision to sell the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg and the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo.

(2) That in making its inquiry the Standing Committee consider a report by a government committee of inquiry, known as the Allison-Brewster Committee, which recommended continuation of the Government Clothing Factory.

I wish to draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that in 1962 the Menzies Government established an independent committee of inquiry to investigate the proposal for a new government clothing factory. This Committee, known as the Allison-Brewster Committee, reported to the Government in 1964. It recommended a continuation of the Government Clothing Factory for the following reasons: Firstly, the Services expressed the view that the Government Clothing Factory should be retained for the quick delivery of items in variety. Secondly, many items produced at the Government Clothing Factory are unattractive to or not normally obtainable from private industry. Thirdly, it would be imprudent to depend for the needs of the Services, either wholly or heavily, on the peacetime vagaries of private industry's level of commercial work. Fourthly, in emergencies the Government Clothing Factory would carry the burden of supply until industry slowly became geared to the task.

In view of these recommendations, in 1964 the Liberal-Country Party Government decided that the continuation and development of the Government Clothing Factory was essential. The Department of Defence has listed several main advantages in the procurement of uniforms from the Government Clothing Factory over private enterprise. They are: Stability and reliability, quality and standards, straightforward procurement procedures, technical and design aids, relatively short lead times and, lastly, capacity to produce special items. These points are contained on the Department of Defence list. It should be noted also that Government Clothing Factory prices over a long period have been competitive with the prices of private industry. The Industries Assistance Commission in its report in 1977 agreed, with some minor exceptions, with the recommendations of the Allison-Brewster Committee of 1964.

I have visited the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg and have had discussions with both management and union representatives. I assure the Senate that the factory is very efficiently run. It has adopted a cellular organisational structure with profit centres throughout its organisation. It has the latest numerically controlled machines and its industrial relations record is extremely good. In only one or two years in its long history, which dates back to the early 1900s, has its revenue fallen below its expenses. The previous Liberal Government, after very careful consideration over a four year period, saw fit to keep the Government Clothing Factory going. Surely the Senate should have something better than a philosophical argument before acquiescing in a course of action that could seriously affect our defence preparedness. Further, I believe that the very cogent arguments of the Allison-Brewster Committee in favour of the continuation of the Coburg clothing factory could equally apply to the Bendigo Ordnance factory and that, therefore, these two factories should be considered concurrently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion, which relates to the Australian Government Clothing Factory at Coburg and to the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. Senator Siddons, on the basis of personal observation and experience-if I might say so he has strong qualifications for assessing the merits of such an establishment as the Government Clothing Factory-has made some comments about that factory. I merely wish to make a few observations about the Bendigo Ordnance Factory.

SPEECH.PARA: The first real problem involved is that the Bendigo Ordnance Factory is very important to the economy of a provincial town in Australia-Bendigo. I turn to the Review of Commonwealth Functions-the work of the so-called razor gang-and the short explanation given of what is to be done in relation to the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg and the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. In relation to the Government Clothing Factory, the following comment was made:
Factory to be offered to private sector for sale or lease as a going concern.
Of the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, this was said:
To be sold to private enterprise (with protection of defence interests).
No enlightenment is given as to how that protection is to be achieved. The further comment is made:
Some activities to be transferred to Maribyrnong factory.

I visited the Bendigo Ordnance Factory, albeit briefly, last Monday and the crisis, if I may call it that, which exists at the factory is one of Government-induced uncertainty and anxiety on the part of the staff, the management and the 600 employees. That has been the situation ever since the committee which reviewed Commonwealth functions brought down its report.

I wish to draw attention to a number of issues which should be examined by the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations when the matter is referred to it. First, there is the uncertainty about the future of the factory. The razor gang having made a pronouncement, in what I would describe as an ideological document, on the future of the factory, there have since been numerous actions and statements by the Government which have only added to the confusion about what the decision means. For example, I refer to an item of $800,000 in the Budget for further expenditure at the factory by the Commonwealth in the coming year. Rightly or wrongly, that has been interpreted as indicating some equivocation as to whether it is to be sold. I make the simple point that in Bendigo that factory, which employs 600 workers, has 200 tradesmen and 100 apprentices. That it has those appretices is the result of Government policy. Those apprentices cannot of course all be employed at the factory. A number go out to private industry after they have completed their apprenticeship. In that way the Ordnance Factory is providing a service, a training facility for the provision of skilled tradesmen needed for the economy of Bendigo. There are 20 professional engineering staff at the factory. I mention that only to indicate the balance between the trades employees and the engineering staff employees.

The dilemma for people working at the Ordnance Factory and indeed the people of Bendigo, who are very concerned about this issue, and the equivocal statements made by Government spokesmen, is that if the factory is to be sold to private enterprise the questions arise: Who is to buy it and what does that mean? For what purpose is a private employer, a private company, to buy the Ordnance Factory? Is it to buy it in order to put a computer out of business? Is a company such as Vickers Ruwolt to buy it for that purpose? Is it to do so in order to use the plant and equipment, much of which is very modern and includes numerically controlled machine tools, in the factory itself, in Bendigo? Is it to buy the factory because it believes that it has a contribution to make in manufacturing for the resources boom, which has been the subject of debate here today? Or is such a company to buy it to engage in an asset stripping exercise? Is such a company to buy it from the Commonwealth Government, then sell the equipment, dismiss the employees and engage in a little profitable trading operation based on asset stripping, leaving the work force without anything to do and the economy of Bendigo debilitated? That is one of the things that could happen if the factory were sold to private enterprise.

It could also be said at the moment that if it were not sold to private enterprise the decision announced by the Government would nevertheless be terribly debilitating to the operation of the factory. What could happen-although I would hope that there would be some commitment by the Government to ensure that it did not-is that firms would tend to say: 'The Ordnance Factory is under a cloud. We have a tender for a job but really we do not have the future of the factory, so perhaps we should not accept it'. That is a possibility which is feared by those in Bendigo who are concerned about the future of the factory. Both aspects represent a considerable worry and I would like a Senate committee to consider them and, in particular, to make recommendations about the conditions under which the factory would be sold to private enterprise-if that should happen-and what would happen to the assets of that establishment. I would like a Senate committee to examine, if the factory is not sold, what commitment should be made by the government concerning its future in terms of continuity of orders from the Defence Department. Some 50 per cent of the factory's work results from such orders. I would like considered also the question of continuity of tendering for private enterpise work which constitutes about 50 per cent of the factory's current activity.

The Government must be in a genuine dilemma concerning this matter. It is one on which the guidance of a Senate committee should be welcomed by all concerned. The factory receives a subsidy from the Government of some $5m a year from the Government. A group such as the razor gang could say: 'They are getting $5m a year from the Government. The factory is clearly not profitable, therefore we should get rid of it.' Such a figure should be examined closely. For defence equipment contracts the Ordnance Factory is paid $9.34 an hour per employee engaged on what is a wide range of functions. However, that is a totally unrealistic price compared with what would be demanded by private enterprise for equivalent work. The correct figure would be more of the order of $20 an hour. If some of the more modern, sophisticated machine tools were used the figure would be higher still. Although the Government provides a subsidy to the Ordnance Factory, the Ordnance Factory provides a subsidy to the defence forces. If the factory is sold to private enterprise, will the Government continue the subsidy to private enterprise for defence equipment orders? What I am asking is this: Is the Government really rearranging the deck chairs on the Titanic, as it were, or is it recycling the process in pursuit of an ideological commitment? All these matters have to be considered. As I indicated earlier, they are matters which are causing grave concern in the city of Bendigo.

I have much pleasure in seconding the motion moved by Senator Siddons and in associating myself with the remarks he made about the Australian Government Clothing Factory. I have outlined additional problems in relation to the Ordnance Factory in Bendigo which I believe the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations should consider. It is very easy for a committee of four razor-wielding Ministers, or whatever it was, to sit down and decide such things by adopting a broad brush approach. I believe that the committee, in making such decisions, made no real reference to, and neither discussed nor gave consideration to, the regional economies of places such as Bendigo or the contribution to the economy which something like the Ordnance Factory makes. I commend the motion to the Senate.

The legislation seeks to provide that beautiful island with a chief judge to preside over matters that fall within the normal jurisdiction of a chief judge in other Territories under the control of the Commonwealth. SPEECH.PARA: As the Opposition understands it, two Federal judges are aged over 70 years at the moment. Consequently, one of them could quite conceivably be appointed to the position in Norfolk Island; for example, Mr Justice Dunphy. He is fortunate in that the legislation passed by Parliament at its last sitting requiring judges to retire at the age of 70 years was not made retrospective. As he had already passed that age, it cannot apply to him. There is nothing in the legislation to suggest that the Government intends to appoint someone such as Mr Justice Dunphy. It provides that the judge appointed must be a judge acting under the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth and appointed by one of the courts for which, under the Constitution, the national Parliament is responsible. Of course, if the appointed judge ceases to hold a position in that jurisdiction he will cease to be the chief judge of Norfolk Island.

I do not want to enter the controversy about salaries other than to say that the last Remuneration Tribunal determination made substantial awards to judges. Those awards will obviously apply to whoever is selected for the position created as a result of the passage of this legislation. In the Tribunal's determinations of 1980 and 1981 very substantial salary increases were awarded to the judges described as judges of the High Court, judges of the Federal Court and judges of the Supreme Court. As I understand it, the appointment will be made from the latter category. It is worth mentioning that the award increases vary between $8,000 to $12,000 in actual salary, with much more reasonable increases in allowances.

Norfolk Island has come of age. One does not have to visit Norfolk Island to realise the tremendous suffering that took place there in the early days as a result of Australian settlement, the suffering of convicts who were placed on Norfolk Island as a result of the judgment of judges. Fortunately, in this day and age the judgments that the chief judge of Norfolk Island will make will probably be less horrific and less likely to be of a nature that we could take exception to. Certainly, we could take exception to some of the decisions made in the early penal colonies. Some people may take the view that the passage of this legislation will create a sinecure for one of the judges in the Federal jurisdiction. When the Opposition looked at the legislation in totality, we realised that in fact it would give the same classification and status to Norfolk Island as exists in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. To that extent, we are pleased to give our assent to the Bill and expect its speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am indebted to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) for his courtesy in relation to this matter. I do not want, if I can avoid it, to use too many words like 'horrific' in talking about the Budget. That seems to happen with every Budget. Everybody says something like that. I want to deal with some of the major themes and issues in the Budget which seem to me to be important. In 1975 Mr Fraser promised to cut taxes in order to restore the incentive to work harder. He was talking about tax cuts for the rich. Since then the Government has been in office for six years and in each of those years taxes have increased, and they have increased most of all for those who could least afford to pay them-the poor. Since 1975 we have had income tax cuts in real terms for the wealthiest 2 per cent of the population. Those earning $40,000 and over have maintained their status-even after this Budget-of having lower income tax than they had in 1975. For the other 98 per cent of the population tax has significantly increased. That is what restoring incentives has been all about for the Fraser Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget is but a continuation of the trend in redistribution of income which has been engineered by the Government over a number of years. If we penetrate the soporific and sometimes misleading prose of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and look at the figures we will see that this Budget not only continues the regressive redistributional trend of the Fraser Government in earlier years but also in fact accelerates it. Sales tax receipts are to rise by nearly 40 per cent in one year. That is more than they have risen in a decade. It is probably more than they have ever risen in the space of a year. The shame is not just that this Government has misled people by promising lower taxes and every year for six successive years has given them higher taxes; but the disgrace is compounded by the way in which taxes have been raised. They are to be paid by those who can least afford to pay them. An increase in sales tax represents at best a flat tax on the consumption of all Australians regardless of their capacity to pay. In effect, it may be more regressive than that. Sales tax on floor coverings, white-goods, crockery and bedding is to be doubled. As those things are general necessities for family life the poor may well pay a greater percentage of their income in increased sales tax on them than the wealthy.

Only a few months ago the Treasurer said that 'any moves towards greater reliance on indirect tax' would not be introduced 'without providing a noticeable offset in personal tax reductions'. Those assurances now stand as a sort of cruel joke at the expense of the Australian taxpayer and voter. Mr Howard has identified himself as a Fraser man to the bootstraps. He says one thing before an election and does another thing after. In fact, as we have seen, pay as you earn income tax has gone up dramatically more than ever before under this Government. Pay as you earn income tax for wage and salary earners will increase by 22 per cent, or over one-fifth, in money terms. That is a record for the present Government. The PAYE tax will be increased to double the predicted rate of inflation. At the same time income tax paid by the self-employed will rise by only 5 per cent. There is to be a fall in income tax for non-wage earners of 5 per cent in real terms, having regard to predicted inflation. To be fair, it should be said that the figure of 5 per cent in respect of self-employed persons partly reflects a fall in farm income due to the drought. But it reflects more than that; it reflects the growing burden that is being placed on taxpayers by tax avoidance. Tax avoidance is budgeted to continue to cost $300m this financial year. In fact, it is likely to be more.

The greater increase in the PAYE take will be increased 'by stealth', to use Mr Fraser's memorable words when this Government introduced tax indexation. Again the shame is not just that broken promises on tax indexation exist but also the fact that Mr Fraser chooses to use methods of revenue raising that he himself has condemned as corrupt and dishonest. The outrage, as I shall demonstrate clearly, is that this form of tax increase 'by stealth', as the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has put it, hits the poorest taxpayers hardest. The reason is simple. Tax is increased because as people receive wage increases a greater proportion of their income becomes taxed at a higher rate. Those already paying a large proportion of their income at the higher rate, like those who are sitting in this Senate, have little to fear because a rise in their salary will not send them into a higher tax bracket, but it is quite different for the poor in this country. As a matter of fact, in line with trends established by this Government the poorer the wage earner you are, the more your tax will increase. After the first two Fraser Governments, the real after tax income for a family living on the average minimum award wage had been eroded by 11 per cent in real terms compared with the position in 1975. Families on average weekly earnings had suffered a cut of 7 1/2 per cent in real after tax income. In the last two Fraser Governments, tax cuts were only for the wealthy. This Fraser Government has imposed a tax the equivalent of about $10 a week on all families not classified as disadvantaged by abrogating Federal Government responsibilities in relation to health care. That is even more regressive than a flat income tax which charges people a fixed percentage of their income. That is a potted history of the Liberal-National Country Party's record on the distribution of income.

Now let me look at how this Government's non-indexed tax scale will hit the less wealthy hardest. Taking the assumptions on wage growth that the Treasurer made in the Budget we get the following sorts of figures: A wage earner earning $14,500 a year will gain a 13.5 per cent wage increase in money terms but his tax will go up by 17 per cent in money terms. A wage earner on $12,000 will see his tax increase by more-by 18 per cent in money terms. A wage earner on $10,000 will pay 20 per cent more tax. A person living near the poverty line, on $6,000, will, with a wage rise of 13.5 per cent, according to the Budget prediction, have a tax rise of 33 per cent. These are the realities of the Government's own predictions in the Budget Papers.

I might say that in the last week or two we have heard these absurd yardsticks which Government supporters have used in discussing things as diverse as interest rates and sales tax. It has been said by Government spokesmen: 'Sure, interest rates have gone up and the sales tax is going up but average weekly earnings have gone up by more'. This notion of some sort of political trade-off with these sorts of figures is absurd.

Some honourable senators will remember that a fortnight or three works ago the Prime Minister, in talking about industrial relations, said that the Government might put a dampener on interest rates in exchange for wage restraint. What an extraordinary concept in terms of a trade-off. The sales tax and the average weekly earnings trade-off is a figment of the Prime Minister's imagination. Indeed it is a figment of Senator Carrick's imagination also. He used this tactic today at Question Time. It is absurd. When we talk about distribution of wealth in this country we are not talking about the people who are on average weekly earnings and above. We are talking about the 60 per cent or more who are in receipt of below average weekly earnings. They are the people whom this Parliament ought to be concerned about. Real hardship is being felt by them.
Let us look at the situation of families under the Fraser Budget. Seeking re-election 10 months ago the Prime Minister said to the Australian people:
It is our belief that the strength of Australia depends upon the strength of Australian families.

I do not know what he meant by that when I look at the Budget. Perhaps he thinks strength arises in adversity for most Australian families but not for his type of family. Let us look at the tax position of Australian families after this Budget. Firstly, by failing to index the spouse rebate-I do not necessarily say that it is a good thing that the Government should do that, but in its terms the family is important-tax increases will hit those with dependants considerably harder than single income earners. A single income family on $14,500 per annum, approximately average weekly earnings, will receive a tax slug, or increase, of 21.5 per cent-an increase of over one-fifth. Again, the poorer the family the greater the tax impost. A single income family on $12,000 per annum will pay 25 per cent more tax. That is a tax bill that grows by a quarter in one year. A family on $10,000 per annum will see a tax increase of nearly a third. A family on $8,000 will be taxed 57 per cent more next year than this year.

This is not taking into account the effects of the increased sales taxes. The Government's health scheme calls them disadvantaged Australians. It is a very good description. Mr Howard expressed his view with the rhetorical question: 'What is wrong with the distribution of wealth in Australia?' What did the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, have to say about it? He was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald quite recently as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: While there may be some Australians living in relative poverty-compared to the incomes of Australians generally . . . I believe there are very few Australians who lack the basic subsistence requirements of life.

I invite the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Social Security to perform a few simple calculations. I invite them to think about a lone parent caring for four children on a $120 weekly pension. I invite them to think about lone parents, as a matter of fact, without making monetary calculations. According to the Smith Family organisation, for a lone parent with four children approximately 63 per cent, or $76 a week, will go in rent. That is $76 out of $120. That leaves less than $10 per week per person for food and other necessities. Does Senator Chaney think that such a family would not lack the necessities of life? There are in this country, unfortunately, 172,000 lone parent families. I invite the Ministers to look at a mature unemployed person with dependants. For some reason such people have been downgraded by this Government, even next to other pensioners. This Budget increases unemployment benefits by $5 a week, leaving unemployed people $11 a week behind the level of benefit they received in 1975 when the Fraser Government came to power. I invite the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and Senator Chaney to consider the position of a young person under 18 years of age who does not wish to or who cannot live at home. What is such a person to do with $36 a week? What sort of self-respect will the person just out of school have when he or she is forced on $36 a week into a hostel or out on to the street? Is it any wonder that the clientele of the Smith Family organisation has grown from 57,000 to 90,000 in just four years? Despite government cuts in funding grants to that organisation, the figure has risen from 57,000 to 90,000 in just four years.

The poor are just some of the people footing the bill for this Government's austerity program. Spending in real terms on health has fallen 22 per cent. Low cost housing relief is down a massive 59 per cent in real terms, at a time of acute need. If Mr Fraser, Senator Chaney or the Treasurer want to know about that they should ask the Victorian Liberal Government Minister for Housing. He will tell them about that because he knows what it is about. He does not go to Perth and say that there could not be poverty there because it is such a beautiful city; he goes to places like Fitzroy and Kensington in Melbourne, to mention two suburbs, where there are very real problems in relation to low cost housing. Mr Kennett is a man with whom I could scarcely conceive that I would have any ideological agreement but I have a lot of admiration for him and his style, and for the command he has over his portfolio. He knows what low cost housing is about and I could utter no words more critical of the Fraser Government's attitude to housing than those uttered by Mr Kennett.

Funding for low cost housing is down a massive 59 per cent in real terms. Education is down 2 per cent in real terms, with money for public state school down more dramatically and funding to private schools up equally dramatically. At the same time, assistance to mining and manufacturing industries has gone up from $151m in 1975-76 to $524m this year. That is an increase of just under 200 per cent in real terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is looking after your mates.

—Funding for the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation has gone up 100 per cent since 1975-76. Perhaps Senator Primmer should have saved his interjection for the next paragraph. The Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet has raised its appropriation significantly, as has the Treasury. That is why the other departments of this Government have been consistently told to cut back expenditure. It is part of the value system of the Fraser Government, which is pulled by a sort of Gang of Four mentality. The wool has been pulled over the eyes of all these grey senators sitting here tonight.
—There aren't many of them.

—No, there are not many of them. The Government has saved $212m by shortchanging the mature age unemployed; it has increased the unemployment benefit from $54 to $58. Without indexation, that represents a loss of about $11 a week. The Government has saved $272m by freezing the employment benefit for under 18-year-olds at callous figure of $36 a week. It saved $240m by shortchanging pensioner families with children so that it could allow for a $300m revenue shortfall in tax collections due to tax avoidance. That is a part of the value system of the Fraser Government Budget. Why has the Government done all these things? Is it so that it can pay to industry over $200m in a program of export incentives which are daily sabotaged by the same Government's own policies of appreciating our currency, or is it so that it can give to industry $500m to subsidise the replacement of men by machines? Perhaps, in part, they are necessary policies but in the hands of this Government they are not well thought out policies.

SPEECH.PARA: They are some of the fundamental issues that concern the Opposition about this Budget. That is something of the Opposition's response to the Budget, considering it as a social document. Of course, this Government's great claim before the Australian people has been that it is a fine manager of the Australian economy. It is a claim that looks a little hollow in the light of some of the things it has done. I refer to the handing down of that great document, the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions. That review was so ad hoc in its approach that pages of the final draft of its report are blacked out with printers ink. It was a review so hastily and shoddily put together that, as a cost cutting measure, it abolished one committee which was giving its services voluntarily to the Government.

How does the claim of efficient economic management over five years stand up against the fact that more than half of the advisory committees abolished by the Fraser Government were created by it in the previous five years? Of the committees abolished by the so-called razor gang, three-quarters were created by Liberal-Country Party governments, half of them in the period of government of the present Prime Minister. Does that represent economic efficiency over a period?

How does the Budget stand up as an economic document? Whatever its social consequences, how will this Budget affect the health of a mixed economy such as that of Australia? Again we see amateurishness and, ultimately, incompetence. This Government has for some time refused to impose a rational resource rental tax. It has refused to do that against the advice of its Treasury and against the advice of almost everyone except the mining lobby. What has been the result? The result has been the introduction of State resource taxes, and now this Government has imposed a duty on steaming coal. We have State resource taxes instead of a Commonwealth resource tax, and now we have a duty on steaming coal-a de facto resource rental tax ineptly imposed. Instead of being a tax on profits it is a tax on production which jeopardises coal operations which are only marginally profitable. It is a tax which will discourage production. Much more alarmingly, it is of course to be seen in the Budget's overall strategy. The overall strategy runs something like this, as it is set out in the Budget Speech:
Real growth over 1980-81 was 4 per cent. This is too big a growth, and it must be wound back, or inflationary pressures will get out of control.

Accordingly, the Government proposes to remove about $1000m more from the economy than it intends to put back. I refer honourable senators to page 11 of Budget Paper No. 1 where we can see that the figure of 4 per cent has been made up by two half-yearly figures. Growth for the first half of 1980-81 was running at an annual rate of 6.1 per cent. Then, dramatically, interest rate rises started to bite. A number of extremely large development projects faltered, credit sensitive industries went into rapid decline and other industries postponed and cancelled developments. Accordingly, the annual growth rate for the second half of 1980-81 was severely cut back to 1.6 per cent. That 1.6 per cent is the lowest annual growth rate figure produced for five years and the third lowest for the decade. In the face of that, the Government is brazen enough, dishonest enough or just plain incompetent enough to predict non-farm growth in 1981-82 of about 3 1/4 per cent. I would like to know whether Mr John Stone agrees with those estimates or whether the emperor has again lost his clothes. It would not seem to me to require a great clarity of vision to see that, if an economy growing at 1.6 per cent per annum is depressed, it is hardly likely to grow at double that rate.

That is the reality of this Budget's overall strategy. It is a strategy which, by its own admissions and on its own forecasts, will see higher employment, lower profits, higher inflation, possibly higher interest rates and further depressed living standards. This is the sixth year of Fraser Government management. It is the sixth year of bad medicine. It is the sixth year in which the patient has received bad medicine but has not seemed to get any better, and there seems in this sixth year to be no hope of a cure.

One more aspect of this Budget needs to be attended to, one final issue or theme to which I want to refer. About the first substantial issues to get a mention in the Budget Speech are wage demands and industrial disputes. We are told that the Budget was framed with a view to tackling those things. This was foreshadowed about a week before in a statement made by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Viner, and Mr Fraser on their so-called wages policy, in what might be called the apres royal wedding summit drinks instead of the pre-royal wedding industrial summit drinks. They announced in that statement what was euphemistically to be called a wages policy. Their wages policy, in the absence of wage indexation, amounted to saying that they had no wages policy at all. I quote from the editorial in the Australian Financial Review of 3 August 1981, which states:

The nearer the end of indexation came the more the total lack of direction the Government in the vital industrial relations and wages areas became apparent. Rather, it has weakly back pedalled on its formerly tough approach in the Arbitration Commission and hoped to the very last moment that indexation, partial, flexible or otherwise, would survive in some form . . .
The Arbitration Commission certainly tried hard enough to keep indexation going . . . But the Government never gave it sufficient support to make the effort any longer worthwhile.

So, instead of a wages policy Mr Fraser announced his intention to use monetary policy, tariff cuts and an appreciating dollar to contain wages. This is the underlying strategy of the Budget. He was opting for a market approach to wage fixation and, given his ideological preferences, such an approach cannot be described as surprising.

It has long been recognised that market forces cannot be used as being acceptable in industrial relations areas, as they can in many others, for a number of reasons which I would be happy to discuss at any other time. But this Government's only wages policy is market forces. Business in Australia, confronted with that wages policy, should be beginning to ask itself what it will cost a business to test the resolution of employees in the market, to test the viability of a market forces wage policy. What will it cost them? I can tell them now, this social experiment on which the Fraser Government is embarking in wages policy, as it is embarking on social experiments in every other area of government activity, will cost them millions of dollars. In 1979 it cost well over four million man days in Australia. That is about $200m in lost wages, and more than that in lost production.
