In Austria, by contrast, to mention one other country which has a wages policy, and which has, perhaps coincidentally, a Democratic Socialist government-I do not think it is coincidental, but it has one-and which uses the centralised wages bargaining system rather than the market, 800 man days were lost in 1979 through strike action. The figure in Austria was 800 man days in comparison with a total of four million man days lost in Australia. That is less than one-twentieth of one per cent of Australia's rate in per capita terms.

Market forces can be used to dampen wage growth in two ways. Firstly, they can be used to reduce profits, thus lowering the overall prosperity in the economy and making it harder for businesses to agree to wage rises. That is one way of doing it, a sort of big stick approach. Secondly, the market can be used to create unemployment, which worsens the bargaining position of employees. I would argue that this Budget was intended to do both of those things and that this Government's only response to the prospect of wage push inflation, its only wages policy, is summed up in two words-more unemployment. As the prospect of wage push inflation will be with us for some time, that fact has ominous implications for the long term. It means that whenever the economy threatens to recover this Government, fearing a bout of wage inflation, will seek to ensure that market conditions exist which will prevent wage inflation. That means higher unemployment.

If we think about that, a new paradox opens for this Government in terms of this Budget strategy. This Government has always handed out its tough medicine using the lure of economic growth. The Australian people have been told that with enough belt tightening, enough bankruptcies, enough unemployment, we could pave the way to a new economic order, a new economic boom. They have been told that our only cure for our ills as a nation-they have been told that for six years now-is contained in those three words which mesmerise the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Howard)-sustained economic growth. But when for the first time under the Fraser Government the signs of sustained economic growth appear-as they began to appear a few months ago-this Government immediately warns that excessive wage demands will jeopardise that sustained economic growth. So its reaction is not to formulate a long term wages policy, which is what it ought to be doing, but to dampen wage anticipations and growth by creating more unemployment.

We used to be told that the only true cure for unemployment, the only road to full employment, was sustained economic growth. Hundreds of thousands of Australian kids have been told that. They have been told that they are not getting better unemployment benefits and they are not getting such things as the Community Youth Support Scheme because the Government knows that the only true and correct road to full employment is sustained economic growth. This Budget is significant for one thing. The great untruth is finally out. This Budget represents a tacit admission, and it has been made by the Fraser Government for the first time. We have been told that sustained economic growth will not cure unemployment. Far from economic growth being the cure for unemployment, the strategy is to seek to base economic growth on a foundation of sustained unemployment. By handing down this Budget the Fraser Government has pronounced itself Australia's first government of permanent unemployment as a strategy for the economy of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a strategy by the Government.

—I am indebted to the honourable senator for his observation. We will hear from him later. What concerns me is that the sad thing about people like the honourable senator is that they probably were never told. I believe his instincts about this matter are completely decent, and if he had had any say in this Budget then it might have been better. But he had not any say at all, so I do not know why he wastes my time with interjections.

SPEECH.PARA: From the Opposition's point of view, we see a need for a much more constructive and responsible Budget in 1981-82. We need a Budget with a different economic premise from the Government's. The Australian Labor Party does not believe that this Government's severe contractionary measures are appropriate when applied to an economy which is already showing signs of an alarming slow-down. We believe that a non-farm economy, growing at a present rate of 1.6 per cent, is not much to be proud of in Australia. Accordingly, we would like to see the Government produce a more balanced Budget or even a mild deficit, rather than the $1,000m tax slug which the Government has imposed. Our priorities would be different, both in the revenue and the outlay areas. We would like to see hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money saved by ending the investment allowance which at present costs $500m. We would like to see, as would the Treasury officers, the Government's economic advisers, a resource rental tax imposed on the mining industry. Those measures would enable relief in direct and indirect taxation to be given to all Australians. We would not want to see sales tax increases proceeded with.

Given the massive pay-as-you-earn income tax increases forecast for 1981-82, we could readjust tax scales to give relief, particularly to low and middle income earners. In fact, a few months ago the Treasurer, Mr Howard, said that he was going to do that. He said that any increase in sales tax would be accompanied by relief in relation to income tax. That has not happened. I suppose it is being kept for the pre-election bonus. A Labor government would adopt more stringent tax evasion measures. At present tax evasion costs the Treasury at least $300m a year. We would like to see that staff ceilings do not operate in important government departments, such as the Taxation Office, where the Government has created an inefficient and understaffed Public Service, unable properly to monitor and police revenue collection procedures. Some estimates of revenue forgone in this way have been as high as $1,000m.

Money thus saved, and a less stringent monetary policy, would enable a sensible government to start pegging back some of the Fraser Government's attacks on the disadvantaged. It would also enable a sensible government to move towards paying the $800m-plus bill that Mr Fraser has taken from the needy by stealth-to use his own expression-by not indexing benefits and allowances. It would enable the necessary expenditure to be made in a number of areas where the Government is saving a pittance, but prejudicing community initiatives and government services alike. The razor gang abolished some things-perhaps little things in the broad context-such as the Victorian Aboriginal Legal Aid Service, which closed down because of a lack of $50,000; the public broadcasting movement; and standards in children's television. Fees were imposed for second university degrees. It abolished things such as youth assistance and women's refuges. In Budget terms these are small things but they are very important to groups in our society, and they are the sorts of values which a decent and honest society would espouse.

In addition, an Australian Labor Party government would seek to develop a constructive solution to industrial relations problems in this country. The Government's failure to do that lies at the core of its Budget strategy. At times governments of either political colour must stand up to irresponsible action by employees or employers. But that is not an industrial relations policy, and it need not be a recipe for constant warring between government and unions. In addition to working towards a wages, prices and social wage policy, in consultation with trade unions and employer groups, we would seek, as we have done in the past, to bring constructive and long term reforms to the structure of the union movement and the arbitration system in this country. We would seek to unify industrial regulation by constitutional change if necessary. That would increase predictability, unity and rationality of arbitration. It would increase the confidence of employers and employees in the arbitration system. In addition, we recognise that industrially we have plenty to gain by moving away from the currently craftbased unionism, towards industry-based unionism.

All of these things are important to consider as alternative strategies which any sensible, progressive government might adopt. When the Australian Labor Party was last in office and sought to facilitate the amalgamation of unions along the lines suggested, that initiative was blocked by the Liberal-National Country Party Opposition. In the 1980 election campaign the Fraser Government promised action along the lines of the legislation which it blocked in 1974. Six years later there has been a lot of water under the bridge, a lot of industrial disputation, and a lot of money has gone down the drain. In the 1980 election campaign the Government promised it would do something about that. After the election this Government ditched its brief commitment to structural reform in the industrial relations area and, instead, introduced some token legislation which has been condemned by almost all reputable authorities.

There can be no doubt that the matter of industrial relations is central to this Budget, and the desire to contain wage growth using the market is a central clue to the unusual severity of the Budget. We are to go through another recession. The poor will be paying more and unemployment will grow because this Government cannot find any other solution to Australia's industrial relations problems. As I have said in this Senate on a number of occasions, only three Western nations have maintained full employment throughout the last decade. They are Austria, Sweden and Norway. None of those countries has a market approach to industrial relations. All of them have industry-based unions. All of them are benefiting from the policies of democratic socialist and social democratic governments, from enlightened, humane and responsible approaches to economic matters. We would move towards those sorts of solutions to our problems in Australia. We would not seek solutions, as the present Government has, in the social and economic nostrums of the previous century. We would not seek to make this country a social laboratory for cruel experiments in economic theory, where the poor are the guinea pigs and the wealthy have time to study the experiments and feel no pain from the results.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Budget that is before the Senate and to make a few comments on Budgets in general and on particular elements of this Budget. I was a little surprised that tonight the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) did not raise an even greater head of steam than he did. I am not sure whether that is evidence of his growing maturity or tolerance or whether he sees in some parts of this Budget at least a worthwhile contribution to an economy that is judged by many people to be a successful economy.
—By whom?

—I will answer that directly, Senator Walsh. Before I continue with my main remarks, perhaps I might comment on one or two things that the Leader of the Opposition said. I note that he referred to this Government's great tax increase. I believe that is something of a distortion in the sense that the tax increase, of course, relates to volume and not rate. If we go back to, from Senator Button's point of view no doubt, the halcyon days of Mr Whitlam's Government, we will find that in one year the amount of tax paid by Australians increased by 46 per cent when wages increased by 23 per cent. I think it is fair that we should have our attention drawn to the fact that there is a difference between volume and rate. The amount is relevant to the earnings of the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button referred also to the increase in interest rates and the consequent increase in costs, in particular, home building costs, which no one would be pleased about. Then he went on to say that the fact that average weekly earnings were up by a very much greater amount-some $220-odd a month in the last three years-was adjudged in some way to be a trade-off. A trade-off with whom? A trade-off for what? Those are facts. They are not relevant to trade-offs and there is no way in which they can be construed as such.

Senator Button further mentioned that this Government was reputed, by itself and by others, to be a fine manager of the economy. I really do not believe that Senator Button thinks it is, yet I must remark that the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development rates it as probably the most efficient economy in the developed world today. Although the OECD may not have members with the capacity in economic fields of Senator Button and others it has, I understand, some very significant economic brains in its make-up. The honourable senator went on further to suggest that the Government has a policy objective of creating more unemployment. I honestly believe that no one in Australia could believe that that is the objective of this Government or of any other government. To create unemployment is to create insuperable problems. Any government which seeks that as an objective will find itself with a very short term of office.

Finally, Senator Button referred to some of the policies that his own party would follow if in government. His party would seek to abolish the investment allowance, an amount of $500m, and it would seek to introduce a resource rental tax. All I can say about those policies-they are only two of the consequences of a socialist policy-is that there is no shadow of doubt that they would be significant deterrents to the development pace of this country. If they were deterrents to the development of Australia they would be deterrents to employment, living conditions and working conditions throughout Australia.

Budgets very often create a great deal of concern, loss of temper, distortion and confusion and, really, they should not. A Budget crops up in the national field, in the field of the Government, every 12 months. Budgets relate constantly to corporate and private business and, indeed, to every family in our community. So a Budget should be regarded as a normal event, as something which has to be analysed sensibly and constructively. Budgets must have responsibility as one of their main facets. In establishing expenditure and revenue patterns one has to be responsible in the first and final instances to the taxpayers. Taxpayers right across the board are the providers of the revenue with which governments seek to follow their various policies.

A realistic analysis of a Budget situation is an absolutely essential operation by a government, an opposition and, indeed, by the Australian people. Distortion and confusion, sometimes aided and abetted, unfortunately, by the contributions of the media and other people, do nothing but disservice to the community which the Budget is drawn to serve. The Budget is a blueprint for an interdependent community. Let us never forget that this community is totally and absolutely an interdependent community. Circumstances which affect any part of it significantly affect virtually all other parts.

A Budget, in the context of a free democratic society, must express the political philosophy of the party or parties which happen to be in government. Indeed, one could assume that if the Australian Labor Party were the Federal Government in this country today it would be expressing through its Budget the philosophy of a socialist system. It would be expressing through its Budget the implementation of the socialisation of the factors of production. That is its province and that is its undertaking. It is the important province of the Australian electorate to recognise and analyse this fact. Similarly, in the case of our own Government bringing down a Budget-as it has for 1981-82-amongst other things it expresses in some real sense its own political philosophy, the political philosophy of a free enterprise democracy, a political philosophy which highlights the security and the dignity of the family unit and equality of opportunity. Indeed, in Australia we live in a country where equality of opportunity is as great or possibly greater than it is in any other country. We believe in the institution and operation of the profit motive within the law, within a properly constructed legal system developed by majority opinion and imposed by majority opinion.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have seen that in operation. That is why there is horse meat in the United States now.

—I am sure, Senator Walsh, that you will have an opportunity to enlighten the Senate at some appropriate time. The profit motive probably goes further towards satisfying human nature than most other ideas and ideals that have been developed. We believe in a philosophy which sees fredom-and this is immensely important at a time when terrorism stalks around the world and disruption is found almost everywhere-as meaningful only if it is freedom within a disciplined circumstance. It is essential that we recognise these things and that we apply them in the implementation of a socio-economic order that is literally dictated by the sorts of Budgets that governments bring down. In our view the state is here to be the servant of the people and not the master. We see the state as a social service-based state in which free enterprise can move as long as that basic element, the needy, the aged and the infirmed, are properly and decently cared for. So the state should be the servant and not the master of the people. It should prevent exploitation of man and his environment.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget seeks to consolidate and develop a position which has grown over several years and which, by all economic and social standards, is excellent by comparison with any country. I mentioned earlier in my remarks that the OECD view--

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, it is not. Have you ever had a look at Austria, or Norway, or Sweden or the Netherlands?

—I sometimes wonder why the honourable senator does not go there. The OECD view of the Australian economy, as I said earlier in my remarks, is that unquestionably it is on the right track and that at this point it is performing better than other economies in the developed world. Indeed, to coin a Mulvihillian phrase, it says we are running against the run of play. Economies around the world are tending to diminish in their security while the Australian economy is basically strengthening.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen a year in which employment has increased by some 2 per cent. Unemployment, an unsatisfactory situation, is a little more than one per cent better than it was twelve months ago. We have seen a growth rate in the vicinity of 4 per cent. The overall deficit of $146m is almost $1 billion less than the overall deficit last year and the domestic surplus is $1.5 billion. These factors have made a very significant contribution to many things, not the least of which is the hopeful dampening of the escalating interest rate situation which is relevant not only to our own economic circumstance but also to the economic circumstances of other countries. On a percentage basis, the overall deficit in this country today is 0.1 of one per cent of gross domestic product. One would have to describe that as a significant performance in view of the fact that six years ago the overall deficit was 5 per cent of GDP.

At the moment the priority of this Government in the expenditure field lies in defence, in maintaining and developing pensions, in other benefits, particularly for the training of youth, and in foreign aid. Foreign aid has increased by some 18 per cent or, in money terms, $100m. The Australian aid is significant in that it is not tied aid. I have had some contact with the people who implement foreign aid programs among our many friendly neighbours. I believe they make a significant contribution to the countries they serve and to their own country. Their contribution through the aid that they deliver and the expertise that they pass on to the communities in which they live and serve is quite remarkable.

The defence area has seen an increase in expenditure of 16.3 per cent, or, in real terms, 5.3 per cent. I believe that is an expenditure of which Australians should be justly proud. In the next five to ten years, the highly trained and extremely capable defence personnel in all three Services and the development of a sophisticated technological capacity, will make us a meaningful middle ranking power. This will put us in a significantly stronger position referable to our friends and neighbours and referable to our security in the years that lie ahead.

The family allowance has been increased by 50 per cent for the third child and subsequent children. As I think was mentioned earlier by Senator Button, the unemployment benefit for single persons of 18 years and over has been raised to $58.10 per week, a rise of almost $5 a week. Pensions will move up as usual by the full consumer price index movement in November to about $70 for a single person and $116-plus for a married couple. Expenditure to expand skilled labour is up by 22 per cent or $203m. I believe this is an extremely important area. It is expenditure which enables Australia's youth, who in many circumstances may be having difficulties in finding suitable employment, to achieve the skills they need not only to serve themselves and their own desires but also to serve the country through filling areas in which they are needed. Employment training schemes this year in the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training area alone will involve some 100,000 apprentices-5,000 more than last year. The School to Work Transition Program is to be granted a further $8m. I pause for a moment to consider the importance of school to work transition. I want to put forward the suggestion that we should be seeking ways to develop the skills of students who in the final two or three years of their schooling demonstrate a real capacity and ability to become tradesmen, whether electricians, plumbers, brickies, carpenters or whatever. It seems to me we must adjust our education system so that young people can start a trade course in the later years of their schooling and, following two or three years of training at technical institutions, can graduate as fully fledged tradesmen and fill the many places that our developing economy has for them.

An amount of $20m will be spent in training for skills which are clearly lacking in the work force. Such training would be of immense value to those trained and the industries involved. It would mean that Australia need not be looking, and should not need to be looking, for migrants with specific skills. We can and we must train our own people to fill the empty places in this developing country.

I pass quickly over the taxation area. I just remind the Senate of the implementation of half indexation of personal income tax from 1 July at a cost of $495m. I remind the Senate of the tax rebate in respect of the health insurance scheme. This is a significant contribution that in mere round dollars means a saving of some $600m to the Australian taxpayer. The Government, through the health system, will provide full basic medical and hospital treatment to the needy and pensioners. People outside that category will have the incentive of a 32 per cent tax rebate on health insurance premiums, which will significantly reduce the real cost of that insurance.

The Government envisages a move to encourage the small Australian investor through taxation concessions. Although this proposal has not been identified factually at this point, it is clear that the Government is awaiting the report of the special Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System before it makes any decision. I am confident that after the report becomes available significant encouragement will be given to small Australian investors. That sort of encouragement is necessary in a country in which we are concerned to establish a real measure of Australian equity.

I pass quickly across the sales tax proposals. I want to mention one or two things relevant to the Government's determination. This determination has not been taken with joy. No government seeks to increase taxes. No government seeks to increase the load on the taxpayer out of sheer devilry or for any form of enjoyment. In this case the Government seeks to broaden indirect taxes. It seeks to increase by 2 1/2 per cent the existing rates of indirect taxes and to tax some new items at a 2 1/2 per cent level. Incidentally, we should remember that medicine, food and wine are not involved, nor will the excise be altered as it now applies to beer, spirits, tobacco and petroleum products. Nevertheless, the yield from the proposed indirect tax will be $553m in this year and in a full year it will be $892m.

There are good reasons for imposing the new indirect tax. There has to be a recognition that ultimately income from oil levies will fall away, and a responsible government has to have a capacity to replace that money. That is one reason. Another reason, of course, is that an indirect tax is much more difficult to avoid than a direct tax. Tax avoidance has been one of the major problems this Government has concerned itself with over the past few years. It is interesting to note that, in reference to the broader based indirect tax, in Mr Whitlam's time the Asprey Taxation Review Committee was commissioned to report, amongst other things, on indirect tax. The Committee report stated:

. . . the Committee has reached one recommendation that it believes should be acceptable to a broad spectrum of public opinion and is consistent with a wide range of attitudes to social policy. It believes that the weight of taxation should be shifted towards the taxation of goods and services and away from the taxation of income.

That was one of the determinations of the Asprey Committee. Indeed, if the sort of income that is generated by these extra taxes becomes the reason we are able to implement cuts in personal income tax, which cuts will enable Australians to retain more of their earnings and to expend them with the sort of priority they would want, those extra taxes will ultimately prove to be a worthwhile implementation of this Budget. The Budget estimates real income to rise by some 2 3/4 per cent in spite of an allowance for a 13 1/2 per cent wage rise and a 10 3/4 per cent rate of inflation. If indeed those rates are realised it will show that this economy is continuing to move in the direction that has been proved to be accepted by most worthwhile judges as the correct direction.

In concluding my remarks I do not wish to continue with a discussion of the actual mechanics and rates of this tax and that tax. I want to ask the Senate to consider just one or two things in general. I believe the success of this Budget and the attainment of the enormous potential available to all Australian citizens is largely related to two things. I was glad to hear one of them being mentioned by Senator Button. That concerned the solution to the industrial relations problem. Whatever system or plan, whether economic and/or social, this Government has an absolute prerequisite to a successful solution to the industrial relations situation. I hope and believe that discussion and analysis between employers and employees, and indeed where necessary with the Government, will produce a sane system in which we see a composite Australian body going forward without the shocking circumstances that have been in existence for, let us face it, virtually the last 10 years. We have to grow out of, above and beyond those circumstances if we are to utilise the sort of capacity that we have.

Very briefly another thing I want to suggest is necessary for the ultimate development of policies and the Australian potential is the regeneration of what we might call Australian pride and enthusiasm. If there is one thing more than any other that this country seems to have lacked in recent times it is a sense of pride and direction and enthusiasm. There would be no need for this except that in this country there has developed a massive group of knockers who are becoming more and more objectionable and, fortunately I believe, more easily recognisable and so able to be treated by the community as indeed they should be treated. It is enthusiasm that this country needs. After all, in the final resort, any legislation is only as good as the will of the people. The enthusiasm that this country needs could be related to its history-a history of which we should be proud, a history of overcoming all sorts of frontiers, such as problems of communications, distance and so on. We have had a history in both peace and war of being great contributors in many fields. I trust that that enthusiasm will be found. I commend the Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MASON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the normal course of events the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, would be giving the speech of comment on the Budget on behalf of the Australian Democrats. Indeed, Senator Chipp has been the principal architect of that speech. It is fair to say that at this stage. Because of illness Senator Chipp cannot be here to give this speech, hence it falls on me to indicate a viewpoint and a course of action to which all five senators of the Australian Democrats subscribe and which we all support. I stress that point at the outset.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point one has to make is that this Liberal Party Budget has nothing to do with the economic challenges of 1981. Clearly it is designed to look forward to the next election year, 1983. From that point of view the Budget then becomes one of the more cynical economic documents that we have encountered. This year the Government is bleeding the community so that it can pork barrel in 1983, not caring who it tears apart this year and next year in the process. As a result of this there will be many individual bankruptcies; many small businesses will go to the wall. Pensioners will have to go through a great amount of agonising. Young families will do without many of the things they should have including decent accommodation in which to live. This is a very simple thing. I would have thought that any civilised and enlightened society would provide for its people a place to live first of all. We are getting to the stage now where we are denying that to thousands of our people. So much for the Government.

I will turn now to the Australian Labor party. When the Australian Labor Party, on the other hand saw the Budget it had a sudden touch of the Machiavellis. It thought it was going into the business of political intrigue. It honed in on the sales tax. I believe now, of course, the Australian Labor Party has rationalised that it has everything to gain and nothing to lose from forcing an early election. Opposition senators cannot tell me that that was not in their minds somewhere. When we look at the motivation of both the Labor Party and the Liberal Party we must ask how much they are worth between them as far as a long term approach to the problems of this country is concerned. Is there an ounce of vision in either of these approaches?

This has been a time of some concern for the Australian Democrats. This small matter has probably taken up more of our time than it ought to have done, which is a pity. We feel that one of the most significant decisions of conscience-I place it no lower than that-that could be demanded from a new political party was demanded from us on the very first day of sitting. The Liberal Party said: 'Here is the Budget. Accept it as it is. Nothing is negotiable'. The Labor Party members said: 'Come along down the garden path with us. We will hold your hand. Reject all the sales tax Bills completely'. We are conscious that that initiative would succeed or fail on our vote. Indeed, we are fully conscious of our responsibility in this regard. It is one to the people of this country, a responsibility towards stability rather than political intriguing, a responsibility to enable this country to go on in a reasonable way rather than not know from one day to the next-because that is what would happen-what the political future holds. The country would be in a state of crisis.

Therefore, we make absolutely no apology for refusing to offer a knee-jerk reaction to the demands of either the Government or the Australian Labor Party. There have been several reasons for the much publicised delay on which we decided before reaching our final judgment. I suggest that the first was the sheer weightiness and significance of that decision-the question whether this would be a good or useful thing to do. The second reason was the conflicting legal advice which we received on the matter. There was good cause for that because this was a unique situation and one that the lawyers advising us needed plenty of time to consider. There was also the need for the contemplation of significant aspects of the Budget other than the sales tax provisions. I believe that this is where the Labor Party tends to have been one-eyed. There are plenty of things about the Budget, as I will shortly discuss, that one could criticise apart from the sales tax proposals. To the question: Why strike out the sales tax proposals initially? I give the answer that it is part of the Labor Party's policy and philisophy, but is not part of our view point and philisophy. There, I suggest, is the crux of the matter. We, the Australian Democrats, will decide for ourselves what course of action to take, based on what we feel is the right thing to do. I suggest that that is what will happen in the future also.

However, the most important consideration was as to the consequences which the Australian Democrats' decision could be expected to have for the future. We have tried to take the long view, to look into the years ahead-possibly even, I suggest to honourable senators of the Labor Party, to the time when a Labor government may be in office. Honourable senators may say: 'Hear, hear!'. But they should ask themselves this question: Is it actually within the constitutional, conventional or technical competence of the Senate to undertake the grave step of rewriting the Budget, even in its particulars? From the very beginning we sought the best legal advice on whether the Senate could or should amend the Government's sales tax Bills. Initially we were told point blank-I will not go into personalities but we were advised by a thoroughly respectable person-that there was no way in which it could be done; that it would be unconstitutional. Within 24 hours that legal opinion was contradicted. We were told that a very important part of the sales tax package, the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Bill, could in fact be amended. I gather that that is the case, that the Senate could shufflle the schedules around so that the extra sales tax burden would fall on the shoulders of those who could best afford it rather than on those who could least afford it. We are thoroughly in accord with the Australian Labor Party on the desirability of doing that, but perhaps honourable senators from the Labor Party can advise me why they think that it would be better that sales tax should not be imposed on luxuries and that some battler's overtime tax should have to go up as a result. Also, I hope that the Labor Party will explain why it wants to oppose the whole package of sales tax Bills. I would like to know its view on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us have a resource rental tax.

—I understand that the Australian Labor Party has suggested such a tax. It is an interesting proposition. To continue the story of the legal complexities, yesterday afternoon we received sales tax measures which impose a tax of 2 1/2 per cent, to apply from 1 January, on items hitherto exempt. This time the package contained no Bills which amended the exemption and classification schedules. We are now advised that that legislation falls in the area of legislation that the Senate cannot amend but may be subject only to the making of a request to the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: At that stage, we re-examined the pledges made by the Australian Democrats senators in connection with Supply when they went before the people of this country and sought election to this place-as indeed the people did elect them. I should clarify, for the sake of those who may not know, that these pledges by Australian Democrats candidates were statutory declarations. We naturally regard them as being of the utmost importance and significance. The significant sections of the text reads:

That I personally subscribe to and endorse without reservation of any kind, the publicly announced policy of the Australian Democrats, as stated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats, the Honourable Senator D. L. Chipp, that the Australian Democrats, if gaining a position of 'balance power' in the Senate, would not use their voting numbers in such a way as to cause the blocking of supply or money Bills in a manner which would prevent the majority party in the House of Representatives from governing.

That for all purposes and without reservation of any kind, I hereby declare that if elected to the Senate, I shall not cast my vote as a Senator in a manner which would be contrary to the policy of the Australian Democrats as stated in paragraph 3 hereof and thus shall never during my tenure as a Senator, contribute to or cause a situation which, through blocking of supply or money Bills might bring down the Government.

Our conclusion has been that to reject and amend the Bills does not legally and directly affect the pledge that we took never to block Supply. That is a fact, and we concede it to the Labor Party, but-it is an important but-a strong case may be made that it offends the spirit of that pledge and, with honourable senators' permission, we will be the judges of that. We are the only people who will be the judges of it. We need no assistance from outside to make up our minds.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Australian people? The Australian people will judge whether you are fair dinkum.

—As the honourable senator says, the people will judge us. They will see that we have taken what is perhaps not the most obvious or the easiest course in order to ensure some stability in the future; that we are doing what we said we would do. That is something that I commend to all honourable senators. I might add that the Australian Democrats are completely united in the view that I have just expressed.

SPEECH.PARA: We can legally reject Supply Bills but what would be the long term implications of such an action? A respectable view can be put forward that the right of any government, including a Labor government, to create a Budget and govern is inviolate. When a government is elected by the people obviously its Budget is basic to its financial policies. Take that away from it and in some degree you remove its mandate. That is an opinion which is thoroughly respectable and which we feel we must stay with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did Chipp believe that in 1975?

—I ask the honourable senator to bear with me a little longer. I am one of those who regrets the events of 1975. I believe that it was a constitutional crisis. In saying that, I am not necessarily backing the honourable senator. It was something that should never have happened. The reason for making our pledge is that we do not want to see it happen again. We know that the people of this country do not want it to happen again. They do not want any meddling or messing around which will produce the slightest likelihood of its happening again. If Labor Party supporters have not yet learned that I suggest they should listen to their Federal President, who knows more about the subject and has exhibited more sense regarding it than I have heard from their side of politics. I say to them, listen to what Mr Wran said. He said to them something of value, something that they might be guided by to their advantage.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the question that arises: Can we mess around with the Budget a little and if so, how much? Clearly, to reject Bills which would cost the Government a billion dollars would be going too far. I assume that Labor senators would agree with me; I do not know. Is it going to far? It really comes back to a matter of degree, does it not? Clearly the Senate has the right to alter the Budget a little. It has an equal right to alter it a great deal. I suggest that the difference is merely quantitative. That is a dangerous path that would lead the way to the re-enactment of the events of 1975-a constitutional crisis. I hope I have made my point.

Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I can only ask honourable senators on both sides of the chamber to accept our assurance that we have given this matter clear thought, we have taken some advice, and we firmly believe that this view is the correct one. We are encouraged in that belief by the fact that some very eminent members of the Australian Labor Party have taken the same view. We feel that, for the sake of the country, the Labor Party as a whole might well look at the issue in that way. We could put away forever into the history books those terrible events of 1975 and forget what happened. I would like to see a time when all political parties subscribed to the idea that the rights of any reasonably elected government in the House of Representatives should not be usurped again in such a way. I cannot believe that members of the Labor Party do not believe that that should be so.

I read a report in a newspaper the other day of something said by Mr Hurford which struck me as being really Byzantine. Mr Hurford was speaking on the question of whether the sales tax measures should be opposed. He was in Sydney addressing the Committee for Economic Development in Australia-business people. He was putting the point of view that the whole idea of Labor opposing the sales tax measures was not really based on a desire to oppose the sales tax measures but rather was an attempt to persuade the business community that it ought to get together with the Labor Party and persuade the Liberal Party of Australia that, because of all the kerfuffle, legislation should be brought down to curtail the powers of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what you were arguing.

—What does the Labor Party really want? Is it going for the sales tax legislation? What is it doing? When we read comments of that type it is not clear to us just what the Labor Party is about. I suggest that such a suggestion is far too Byzantine for the people of this country to understand in any detail. I turn now to the Budget and give an idea of what the Australian Democrats think is wrong with it; that is, plenty. It involves not just the sales tax issues. What about the Government's promise of full indexation? Whatever happened to Mr Fraser's confident, bold words uttered in the House of Representatives on 12 September 1978, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we said that we wanted to end for all time the deceit of a tax system which, through the process of inflation, brought larger and larger funds to the coffers of government. We said that if governments wanted more funds they should tax for them openly and plainly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—Mr Fraser said that. I am quoting Mr Fraser's words, and I shall go on and quote a few more. Talking about tax indexation-that was when it was fashionable in the Liberal Party-he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would sooner have to defend that method than to be taking more and more money from the people of Australia by the hidden process of inflation and trying to pretend that taxes had not in fact been increased.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—I think the honourable senator did hear me say that, indeed, it was Mr Fraser; I am assured of that. How empty those words ring now. I do not think I need say more than that; no more is necessary. That is one of our main points of criticism of the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the social services area. Although the Government has used that deceitful way of getting more and more money out of the community, no attempt has been made to return money to the community. I suppose that we have to have more and more money for the new and permanent Parliament House and things such as that. The cost of that is now up to $300m, although in 1978 we were given a solemn undertaking that there was no way in the world the cost would go above $151m. I predicted then that before that building was completed its cost would be over $1 billion. I say that again, and I will take an even money bet from any honourable senator who would like to make it that that will be the case. In other words, that is where the money is going to. It is wrong that it should be going into that building.

TALK.START.PARA: —With toilets and showers in every room.

—And what about the contemplation rooms, the meditation rooms, and all that sort of thing? We do not need that sort of thing. We are here to try to be of service to the people of this country. There again, it is another Byzantine idea that we should have these colossal buildings in which we can all luxuriate. What has happened as a result of that? It is not that there is any shortage of money in this country; it is the way in which it is being spent. Of course, the Government then cuts expenditure in other areas in order to finance other things, such as the Strangelove Academy-excuse me, the Casey University, or is it not called even that now? I am referring to the idea of the Indonesian-type military academy that we are to propagate in Australia, in which we will train our officers who now go to an ordinary university and come into contact with civilians, as they should do. We plan to hide them away in a military establishment so that they will not be perverted by any ideas of the ordinary populace. Money is going into that project. How about that? Of course, the Government keeps slashing away at expenditure in education and housing. The Australian Democrats feel particularly badly about education. Every other enlightened society in the world understands that a country is only as wealthy as the extent to which its people are educated and equipped in quantity to deal with the modern world and its competitive nature, especially in the field of high technology. It is madness to reduce spending on education. It is short sighted. In a way, it is a form of national suicide, and we regard it as seriously as that.

SPEECH.PARA: The cut in finance for welfare housing is disastrous. Even quite small cuts in welfare housing finance rapidly exacerbate the situation in poor areas of cities such as Sydney and Melbourne. Immediately there is a bit of a shortage of housing the landlords get a chance to rack-rent even more. The worse the shortage gets, the higher the rents go and the worse is the situation of the people in that accommodation. They are crammed into buildings. I cannot resist saying, because I believe it to be true, that people are crammed into buildings such as the one that burned down in Kings Cross the other day and in which people were killed. That building existed because the economic conditions in housing that have been created in this country promoted its existence. It was not the only one of its kind. Believe me, we will see more incidents of that kind. How shortsighted can we be to expose people unnecessarily to that kind of thing. It is unnecessary. The Government is budgeting now for a huge surplus. It should have had the compassion and sense to try to ensure that finance for those vital areas of education and housing was at least maintained rather than cutting away at it. I suggest that it takes some thought and meditation to plumb the depths of the course on which we are now embarked and which I and the Australian Democrats believe is a tragic course.

With all those things to be considered, our decision was formed by this point: Where is the logic that demands that we should go down only one track, namely, to block sales tax legislation in this House? Logically, if we reject the sales tax legislation because it is inequitable and unjust-I agree that aspects of it are very much so-then why should we not go right in and reject a great deal more of the Budget? It is that proposition and its consequences that we have tried to face squarely and honestly. If we and Senator Harradine-he has to speak for himself but obviously he is an important factor in this-were to go along with the Australian Labor Party and knock back the sales tax Bills completely, what would be the result? One alternative is that the Government would have to accept the situation, in which case a precedent would be established. The numbers in the Senate are fairly close now, and I concede that the electoral system for this House makes that a more or less semi-permanent situation. That course would mean that every future government would face the risk of having at least part of its financial program destroyed. It is a fact that Governments have a mandate for their financial program.

If indeed this Government goes ahead with the sales tax legislation and does not change it, I can assure it that its chances of being booted out in 1983 are very good indeed. People's memories are not that short. Like the bad tennis player, the Australian Labor Party might get back not because of the adequacies of its performance but because the other side muffed it up so badly. This inequitable sales tax legislation is one of the ways in which the Government is muffing it up. Sales tax is inequitable if it is applied to necessities. I wonder how the legislation got though the Government Caucus without at least some Government members understanding that, understanding how widespread throughout the community the realisation would be.

As I said, the Government's acceptance of our blocking legislation would be one alternative. The other alternative is that we would be forced to a double dissolution and, once again, to the crisis situation of November 1975. Are either of those alternatives really in the interests of this country? We do not believe they are. We have an interest in stability. We believe that if either of the two major parties is elected to government it has a certain mandate and a right to exercise it. A small party should not meddle or allow itself to be persuaded by somebody else to meddle with money Bills and legislation of that nature. Supposing we had agreed to the proposition. Does anyone in this chamber or in the country believe that similar action would not be tried again next year and the year after, in constant attempts to harry the Government? The mind tends to boggle at the tactics of any of the major parties in an election year in such circumstances. I ask the Australian Labor Party to consider the reverse situation-with the ALP in government, the Liberal Party in opposition, and it being an election year. We assume that in such a situation the Labor government would bring in a fairly reasonable sort of Budget because of its being an election year.

If the Australian Democrats had accepted the ALP proposals tonight, what proposals would the ALP impact on the 1983 Budget, which might be a less than responsible electioneering-type Budget. Would a Liberal government be forced to accept, say, ALP demands for reductions in sales tax, increases in pensions, and so on, three months before a general election? The result would be a hotch-potch piece of financing which would have been formed completely by a desperate political situation and which probably would throw the country into economic chaos, from which it might take years to recover. That is the prospect as we see it. It would have been very easy for us to come out and say: 'Here we are, we are the Australian Democrats with the balance of power. Yeah, we are going to go in with the Labor Party and we are going to heavy these guys'. Great stuff! High drama! Headlines! Terrific story!

TALK.START.PARA: —You would hate that.

—Well, we were tempted for about 17 seconds, Senator, to be quite honest with you. Of course, we are not going to do it. Our dilemma is that many of the sales tax increases are thoroughly undesirable and their impact is most damaging on those sections of the community least able to afford them. We are not going to ignore that. We are going to move our support motions requesting the Government in the House of Representatives to amend the new sales tax provisions relating to the basic necessities of life, that is, anything which would have an effect on increasing the price of food, medicine, clothing, education or shelter because they are the things that everybody has got to have. I said that sales tax is inequitable if it is applied to those necessities. It is inequitable for this reason: The Government is applying a tax broadly on members of the community without any regard to their ability to pay. This is inequitable. It is a basic principle of tremendous importance. I can assure Government senators that they will find this out at the ballot box before they are much older. There is no doubt about that from the feedback I have had already, not just from party members, but from the community. That has been deeply resented. After 1 January when the effect starts to bite it will be resented even more. Do not think that the people who will have to pay more for their houses and who will be paying more on their mortgages next year will forget by 1983 because they will not. They will remember, you senators opposite wait and see.

SPEECH.PARA: What we of the Australian Democrats are putting is that if a request goes to the House of Representatives with the full authority of the Senate, one House of the Parliament will have said to the Government: 'Don't do this thing'. I would have thought that a government with any respect whatsoever for parliamentary government, one which did not regard itself as a dictatorship, at least would have to consider that request very very carefully. If the Government gets feedback from the community at large, from the public-indeed, I know it must be getting it because we are getting letters-I think it will have to accede to that request. The Government will get peanuts from that section of tax anyway. Everybody is thinking: 'Okay, you are putting it on now so that you can make it higher next year and the year after until you really have the community under your thumb and everybody is paying a fortune for all sorts of things, like children's shoes and school textbooks'. Surely Government supporters do not think that will improve conditions in the community. How could they? If the Government refuses that request the Government alone will bear responsibility for refusal and it alone will earn the contempt of all decent Australians. We will do everything we can to make sure they understand very fully what the Government is doing. We will not let the Government forget it between now and the next election. That is our proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can reject it when it comes back here.

—True; I will go on to that. We are facing that one. We are not dodging that one. True to our word, if the Government takes the reprehensible step of rejecting that request the Australian Democrats will not oppose the passage of that Budget legislation through the Senate. That is definite. It is a considered decision. That is the way it is going to go. Sorry chums, that is the way it is. Undesirable though these sales tax increases are, damaging though their impact may be--

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Listen to this, senators, it is my bottom line. Those on the Labor side in particular should listen to this. Undesirable though the sales tax increases are, damaging though their impact might be, the consequences of the Senate meddling in or unilaterally rewriting a Budget seem to us too horrifying to contemplate.

—Before I call Senator John Coates of Tasmania, I remind honourable senators that this will be his maiden speech in this House. I would ask all honourable senators to extend to him the normal courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President. May I congratulate you on your election as Chairman of Committees. The situation we find ourselves in tonight in which the position of the Australian Democrats on the sales tax Bills is being laughed at by Government Ministers is amazing. If it were not so serious it would be amusing, bearing in mind the Australian Democrats high principles and remembering that their leader was in Mr Fraser's shadow Cabinet in 1975. It was that shadow Cabinet which decided to block not individual tax Bills but the Appropriation Bills which make provision for the ordinary annual services of the Government. I point out that those principles came out only after he was sacked by Mr Fraser.

SPEECH.PARA: I regret that Senator Mason muddied the water further tonight by not making the distinction between tax Bills and the Appropriation Bills. He suggested that if the Senate defeated the sales tax Bills it would be setting a precedent. Of course, it would not be setting a precedent. It has been done many times before. It happened to the Labor Party when we were in government in 1975. The Bill to impose the Medibank levy-a tax Bill-was defeated. Nobody on either side of the House suggested at that stage that an election would result. And, of course, an election did not result in 1975 because other Bills were twice defeated and provided grounds for a double dissolution. The election in 1975 was due to the Governor-General's action over the blocking of the Appropriation Bills. That was the cause of the election. The double dissolution was an accidental side effect and allowed both Houses to go to an election. I regret that the distinction was not stuck to by Senator Mason tonight. I suggest that the main reason for the position taken by the Australian Democrats is that, like the people on the other side of the House, they are more attuned to taxing regressively rather than progressively, though I acknowledge Senator Mason's reference to the fact that the sales tax on the necessities of life, on which he concentrated, would be regressive.

Some people have asked me why I sought to come back to the Federal Parliament, having been a member of the House of Representatives during the period Labor was in government, especially in view of people's attitudes to politicians. They have a relatively low opinion of us. Perhaps I ought to relate an anecdote. Only a couple of weeks ago when I was filling the boot of my car with some goods I had bought I said to the supplier who was helping me to fill the boot: 'Yes, no trouble; they will all fit in the boot'. But, as it turned out, they did not. I commented that the size of the boot was deceptive and he said: 'Well, you are a politician; you would know all about deception'. That sort of automatic response by people-generally they have a low opinion of politicians-certainly does not encourage some people to come back to this place once they have been reprieved.

This Government does nothing to encourage people to modify their view of members of parliament. The broken promises of this Government do nothing to modify that view. The Budget we are debating tonight just adds to people's feeling of hopelessness. Apart from the fact that it is a dull and an unimaginative document it attacks the living standards and destroys the way of life of Australian families and individuals. There is nothing in the Budget to make the average Australian any happier with the Fraser Government. As a result, this feeling flows to politicians generally as far as the Australian people are concerned.

The year 1981 has been called the year of the recycled politician. Michelle Grattan referred to that in the Age of 10 April this year. I am not sure whether that was the original reference but it was the first I saw. That expression arises from the fact that many people in the last year or so have moved, or sought to move, from the House of Representatives to the Senate, either directly or after a term, and from the Senate to the House of Representatives and from State parliaments to the Federal Parliament. I will not go into the details of all the people involved. No doubt the new Parliamentary Handbook will contain it. I was in the House of Representatives as the member for Denison during the two parliaments of 1972 to 1975 when the Labor Party was in government. I make a small political point by referring to the period as two half terms. They were only half terms because of the action of this House under the direction of the present Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). I think the main thing that ought to be said at this point-it refers back to what Senator Mason said-is that the powers of this House constitute the problem and not detailed arguments about legal opinions on existing powers.

I believe when journalists write about recycled politicians they are using the term derogatorily. They are almost suggesting that such people should have been left out to grass. Recycling conjures up images of a rusty old car being crushed into scrap metal, of waste paper being made into some lesser quality paper product, or of an empty bottle being refilled. Others will have to judge whether such a comparison is apt-I hope after leaving a reasonable period before making that judgment. Of course, recycling is a highly environmentally responsible activity-conserving and reusing resources and, perhaps, even improving them.

I hope that I have learnt some lessons from that period in government and the period since so that now I have been transported into what ought to be regarded as the second House of the Parliament rather than the upper House, which implies some superiority it ought not to have. I hope I can make a better contribution on behalf of those who have sent me here than I was able to do before. I will not be able to do that-none of us on this side of the House will be able to do that-other than in a marginal way, unless we win government and so be in a position to implement Labor policies in a positive way. That must be the aim of all of us in the Senate Opposition. I was almost going to say 'on this side of the chamber' but I make a distinction by saying 'Senate Opposition'.

In the meantime, we can try to protect Australia from the worst excesses of Fraserism. We can use committee hearings to expose facts, and develop and promote new policies, but we can really achieve things only if we obtain a majority in the House of Representatives. Even then, we would not necessarily be able to achieve all that we wanted to achieve. Life will be tougher for us, as it was between 1972 and 1975 when we were in government, but that is what we are here for. We would be letting down all those dedicated Labor supporters and workers for our cause if we did not have that aim and work our guts out for it-not just sometime, but in 1983 or sooner.

While I must admit to some mixed feelings about being back in this institution, I am pleased and proud to be back as a member of the Federal parliamentary Labor Party. I would like to express my thanks to all those Tasmanian voters who supported the Labor team in last October's election and especially thank those who voted for me, in particular, for the that honour. I trust I will not let down those people who so deliberately expressed their confidence in me.

I am not sure whether this is a maiden speech. I do not particularly mind about the usual courtesies or anything like that. There are two schools of thought as to whether this is a maiden speech. The first is that one cannot be a maiden twice over and I should, therefore, receive no leeway. The second thought is that this place does not recognise service in the House of Representatives in any way. After all, I have had a break in my parliamentary service. Certainly it makes no difference to me. Before I move on to other matters I wish to refer back to my maiden speech in the House of Representatives on 8 March 1973. I am told that it is bad form to quote oneself, but it is with some wry amusement that I read what I said then. I said:

It was certainly very satisfying to have won Denison for the Australian Labor Party so decisively and, by that, to have played a part in enabling this Government to come into office, and so to allow the reforms to commence. We lost Denison in 1949 when we lost government; we have now regained it as we return to office. If this is significant, I do not mind having my personal political fortunes linked to those of the Party as a whole, because this Government, by its actions and achievements, is going to remain in office for a long time.

It is now history that my personal political fortunes were linked to the Labor Government. We did not remain in office for a long time-more is the pity. I believe we are on the verge of regaining office by winning, among other seats the five House of Representative seats in Tasmania, including Denison. Therefore, in two ways we would be removing the burden of the Denison incumbent from the people of Canberra. One of the points that I made in that 1973 speech-I must say that it seems a lifetime ago now even though it is only eight and a half years ago-was that Labor's political opponents ranted and raved about aspects of our policies and tried to make certain words dirty words-words such as 'peace', 'socialism' and 'caucus'. Their campaign continues but since I am basically an optimist I think we have made some progress since then in reducing the effectiveness of our opponents' campaign. In 1973 I said:

We are a socialist party and we should not be ashamed to say so. I think that the party is itself partly to blame for the past success of the Liberal party, so called, and the Australian Country party-
As it then was-

and others whom I will not name, in their blackening of the word 'socialism'. We have, to a certain extent, ignored the misrepresentations instead of reacting positively and explaining to the people what a modern democratic socialist thinks, and how our policies fit in with that.

Since then the party has made much more of an attempt to use and explain the word. I believe our opponents' misrepresentations have been somewhat neutralised, and they are now much more muted about that criticism. The present Government still makes much of the democratic procedures of the ALP, almost spitting out the word 'caucus'. Again, perhaps that does not occur quite so often as it did in the past. In 1973 I further stated:

The Opposition makes much of the democratic structure of the Labor Party . . . However, our system is perfectly justifiable and in fact gives desirable safeguards to the public, because the electors are fully aware of the basic platform of the party within the framework of which we work. The platform is a public document, resulting from debate at open conferences which are representative of the tens of thousands of Australians who make up the Australian Labor Party, and which anyone who subscribes to the party's principles can join, and join in that decision-making process.

The public knows that the policy they voted for when they supported Labor candidates cannot be changed at the drop of a hat by a handful of people, unlike the policies of the Parties opposite when they are in government.

Of course that did not always work precisely as intended when we were in government, but overall it did and does. I suggest that if members opposite 'caucused' a bit more often instead of just accepting what their leader says their Government might improve as a result. I believe the amusing thing about Government members supporting the Budget Speech of their Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the sales tax measures in particular is that very few of them had any say in the proposal at all. The revenue measures would have been the decision of about three people on their side. Finally, I refer to the word 'peace'. This is another word that members opposing us have tried to denigrate. In my 1973 speech I said:
The other word that, to its everlasting disgrace, the present Opposition--
The present Government-
has tried to make out to be a dirty word is 'peace'. It still makes me sick to think of how the Opposition, when in government, got this nation involved in the Indo-China War.

Our opponents tried to make working for peace equivalent to treason. But now with this distance in time since the Vietnam war even they would have to admit that we were correct. As a result, to support peaceful solutions is now almost respectable. I was speaking in 1973, shortly after the end of Australia's involvement in that war. There are still warmongers on the other side of this chamber, but their position, I believe, is less credible now. I am proud to be part of a socialist party which stands for peace in this world and tries to conduct itself in a democratic way. I think the differences between the parties are much clearer now than they were, especially following the razor gang proposals which the Government is now implementing in getting out of any possible public involvement that it can. I believe the Government would put back the ACT Fire Brigade into private hands if it thought it could get away with it. The ideology of this Government distinguishes it quite clearly from the present Opposition.

I should say something of my attitude to the Senate, as a dedicated former member of the House of Representatives. If I must accept that this place exists, at least I can object to the Senate's powers and the way its supporters suggest not just that its powers are equal to those of the House of Representatives but that they are more than equal. This assertion of power is manifested in many ways, including subtle ways such as those I mentioned before-for example, referring to it as the upper House rather than the second House. I suggest that there is much forelock tugging here which is largely a result of the use of the title 'Senator', a name style I find difficult to get used to although I suppose I will have to. The existence of such a continuously used title is one of the subtle ways in which this place wrongly asserts superiority over the House of Representatives where everyone is plain Mr, Mrs, Miss or Dr, or whatever. At least 'Senator' is a non-sexist term. However, its use also takes away one's given name. 'Senator' becomes almost a new first name, as if one's former identity has been lost.

Another thing which suggests superiority is the six-year term, which I believe is far too long. I do not think anyone elected by the Australian people ought to be able to go for that length of time without having to face them again. A term of four years ought to be quite long enough. People say that the Senate is imporatnt because of the way the House of Representatives performs. I argue that the House of Representatives performs in the way it does because of the Senate. Because of the Senate governments are encouraged to push Bills through the House of Representatives knowing that more debate must occur in the Senate. Because the Senate has a well developed committee system there is less pressure for a proper system to develop in the House of Representatives. Again, the Senate ensures that the House of Representatives is as gladiatorial as it is. I think that is a pity.

I pay a tribute to former Senators Ken Wriedt and Justin O'Byrne. In a way I am succeeding both of them in that whilst it was Justin O'Byrne's term that finished on 30 June-my term began on 1 July-Ken Wriedt was the senator resident in the southern part of Tasmania, having had an office in Hobart. As honourable senators will know, Justin O'Byrne served 34 years in the Senate, which is an incredibly long time to contemplate. He was Labor Whip and for part of the period we were in government he was President of this House. It has been a privilege to know him and I think it is a landmark in Tasmania's history and in the history of the Senate that he is now not in this chamber. If anyone were to be dubbed with the title 'Senator Emeritus', it would be Justin O'Byrne. Ken Wriedt was here for 12 years, including three years as a Minister of high repute and six years as Labor leader in the Senate. It is a great shame that he is not continuing to serve in Parliament. I am particularly indebted to him because, working for five years since 1975 as his electorate assistant, I was able to keep up my close involvement with federal political affairs. Both those former senators were fine representatives of Tasmania and of the Australian Labor Party and it is an honour to succeed them and to represent the Australian Labor Party and the people of Tasmania in this Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In opening my speech on the 1981 Budget, I congratulate you, Mr Deputy President, on your election to the office of Chairman of Committees. I wish you, as I do the President, every success in your term of office. I feel confident that both the President and yourself will perform most admirably in upholding the dignity and ensuring the progress of the Senate. I also congratulate Senator John Coates who has just completed what we might call his first speech in this place, since he shyly draws away from the idea of it being a maiden speech. I know from Senator Martyr, who also bears no resemblance to a maiden, that is a matter of some sensitivity with new senators. One welcomes the interesting observations Senator Coates made and also the modesty which he displayed in describing himself as a recycled politician. I suggest to him with all seriousness that perhaps the expression might better be that he is a reconditioned model rather than a recycled politician-one who has been elevated to higher climes, who has actually now gone on to more extensive and valuable service. Having served a period of apprenticeship in the lower chamber, he now has an opportunity to do his real work in the Senate. I wish him well in his future career.
—He is almost like a phoenix, is he not?

—I suppose he is. If a person suffers an electoral defeat and then comes back, I suppose he rises from the ashes. That is a rather gloomy view and I would rather put it that he is now entering his glorious period of service in the Senate. He may come to the conclusion a little later that the earlier view which he took about the Senate being a place which is somehow to blame for the errors and faults of the House of Representatives may not be so, that in fact the members of that place to some extent may be masters of their own fate and that we are not responsible. I hope that in his work in the Senate he will find that this is indeed a worthwhile chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the Budget. Tonight we are hearing the views of the Australian Labor Party and the views of the Australian Democrats on the Budget. The words that come to me tonight are the words which Senator Chipp used in his campaign. He said the purpose which the Australian Democrats hoped to serve in this chamber was to 'keep the bastards honest'. I think that expression in this day and age is acceptable. Of course I would not apply it to colleagues opposite. I say that keeping persons honest is what I hope we on this side of the chamber will do. Therefore, we will want to observe the various convolutions in the ideas, philosophies and views of the Labor Party, and perhaps even the Democrats, to ensure that they do keep consistent with the views they have expressed over a number of years.

I want to make reference to some of those views and, with loving care, speak of some of the things that have been said in this chamber in previous times by various leading members of political parties, particularly the Labor Party. Since the Labor Party has now entered upon a new version of its rights and activities in regard to Supply and money Bills and is now developing what one might call a pettifogging distinction between those Bills which they feel they can rightly throw out from this chamber-money Bills though they are-and those to which they think it would be wicked to do that, I want to remind its members of some of the things they have said over the years and suggest that, as they think they are now in the full flush of their powers, they should think of those principles and stick to them. I am afraid they are not showing much sign of doing that at present. It is true that tonight the Democrats have indicated that they will not go along with the line the Labor Party has put before them. I think the Labor Party offered to lead them down the garden path but I think Senator Mason's view was that the Democrats are not willing to take up that offer. I am glad to see tonight that they do not propose to take action which would in any way defeat this Budget or any major part of it.

As I have said, the Labor Party has been involved in curious activities and actions in recent months and years. One could say that Senator Button, who has been a proponent of the new line by the Labor Party in regard to Supply, has developed push button principles that are capable of change when he does not need them. I remind the Senate that on 19 June 1979 Senator Button took it upon himself to write an article in which he stated:

The participants in the debate about the issues which emerged dramatically in 1975 have tended to become locked into fixed positions. There is not much room for lateral thinking about the role of the Senate. It is clear, however, that if the Senate continues as it is now, it will lead to a repetition of the '1975 show' at some time in the future. The consequences will be even more divisive and disastrous for the parliamentary system.
I think there is a lot of sense in those words. I do like the Button of 1979. I do not like the Button of 1981 quite so much.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should push it.

—Yes. He recognised the consequences of repetition of this kind of thinking. But apparently he thinks now that it is all right for the Labor Party to pursue such dangerous lines. In the same article he went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, it is necessary to remove the Senate's power over Supply. Secondly, it is necessary to remove its power to totally reject legislation and substitute for it the power to delay legislation for a limited period.

It is very interesting, is it not, to understand that he was then so objecting to the power over Supply that he would remove it; but now of course he would use that power, even though he uses it only over some of the money Bills. Then he wanted not to stop the power of rejection but merely to delay. Now of course we hear nothing on that line at all. Yet the views which Mr Wran, the Federal President of the Labor Party has expressed over the last few days indicate that in the Labor Party itself there is a great deal more care and worry about the exercise of those sorts of powers.
