The way in which the Labor Party has discussed its new set of principles, or its principled course of action as Senator Evans calls it, was set out quite interestingly a few days ago in a personal explanation which Senator Evans made after Question Time. He felt that he had been misrepresented by an honourable senator. He stated that he did not mind being described by anybody as a man of principle, and I will not have any concern about that. But I think he will have to work hard to maintain that role as a man of principle, considering the way in which he went on to argue. He spoke of the way in which the Labor Party could perform and should perform in regard to Bills. He said:

. . . on the one hand Bills which are crucial to the survival of a government, are matters of life and death so far as the existence of a government is concerned and, on the other, those which do not satisfy that description . . .

That is very interesting. Apparently those Bills that Senator Evans finds are crucial are the ones which are not to be touched by the Senate, but if they are otherwise they may be. Who makes the judgment? The judgment is made by members of the Labor Party, Senator Evans; not the Government. They make the decisions on the Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who made them in 1975? The Government?
—If the honourable senator is relying on 1975 as his test then there is a very big change in his attitude.
—I have never changed my attitude to 1975 and you should not either. You have the problem of changing. You have to rationalise.

—No. Fortunately I have no such problem. As you know, I have never found an occasion when I felt that that power should be used. I am in a unique position in this Parliament, and therefore perhaps in a better position to speak on this subject than anyone else in this place, because I have taken the view at all stages that it is only on the most rare occasion that the Senate should exercise that interference power over money Bills, over Budgets and over matters of Supply.
—How did you vote?

—Consequently, I have never made a gesture in a vote. At any stage when I could have avoided that and my persuasive powers were not sufficient to get any support, I could never do so. But apart for that I have, of course, never had an opportunity of voting. I have always opposed the use of that power by the Senate. Consequently I suggest to the Labor Party that it is not in a position now suddently to switch horses and decide at the first opportunity that it has that it can go ahead to take this sort of action in regard to a Budget. Senator Evans went on to say that the Opposition could vote against a number of Bills. He said that there are Bills which should not be touched and perhaps also in that category of packages of Bills that are absolutely essential to the Government's existence are some major taxing Bills, for example, Bills to establish the whole system of personal income tax which accounts for 50 per cent or more of the Government's revenue. Then he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the latter category are included those lesser money Bills which impose fees or fines or make particular appropriations of perhaps a few hundred thousand or even a few million dollars for some particular purpose . . .

There is one Bill in respect of sales tax amounting to $500m or more that the Government says is necessary for the expenditure that is required in this country-an essential part of its Budget. The Labor Party says that that should be voted down. I am glad to see that the Australia Democrats have not gone so far as to agree with any proposition such as that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about when you removed the Medibank levy?
—Of course there have been Bills that have been defeated by Oppositions before, yes, but not parts of Budgets.
—It was part of the Budget. It had to be.

—What the honourable senator is saying is that there are times when Oppositions have voted down Bills. Different governments and different Oppositions have certain principles and certain views. But the Opposition has gone on record time and again as saying that it would not do this sort of thing. Therefore it cannot deny these things. What it is saying is that with Bills for a few million dollars, it is all right. But it will not let a Bill for $500m pass through the Senate if it can stop it. As is pointed out in an article in the Age yesterday, there is a great deal of sensitivity by the Labor Party about its new policy. The Senate leaders claim that there is no change in Labor's policy.
—Was it a policy?
—Yes, it can be called a policy. It is a policy on voting down Government Bills. They say that there is no change in the Labor policies towards--
—What did you do in 1977 and 1978?

—The honourable senator must learn that he cannot turn to someone else having done something which he does not like as a justification for his changing his mind. Unfortunately, he wants us to give him his principles. But he has made up his mind on these things. The Opposition has gone on record about them time and again. I want to tell the Senate what the record says. On 3 July 1981 Senator Gareth Evans gave an address to the National Conference of Labor Lawyers in which he said some interesting things. He spoke of the temptation that would be coming before the Labor Party. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The most obvious is the temptation to block Supply, in the unlikely event that numbers elsewhere were such as to make this a practical option.
We note that the numbers are not here for them to do it tonight. He continued:
The fact that constitutional and democratic principles were torn up in 1975 is no excuse for anyone doing it again.
Remember that. He continued:
While there is a great deal to be said, tactically, for never ruling out completely any option, I believe that our credibility and self-respect as a movement depend on us being more principled--
I suggest that Senator Gietzelt listen to this; it will be useful to him-
than our opponents, and that we would sadly demean both ourselves and our cause were we ever to descend to the Tories' level.
Senator Evans does not want to come down to what he thinks is our level. He wants the Labor Party to stick to its own level, and I hope it will try. He went on to say:

Nor do I believe that the ALP should contribute its numbers in the Senate to the blocking of other kinds of legislative measures in respect of which the Government can reasonably claim some kind of express or implied electoral mandate. I acknowledge that a good deal of nonsense is talked by parties of all colours about electoral 'mandates'.

Senator Evans is certainly quite correct about that, but the fact is that there is, of course, an implied mandate for a government so recently elected to then put before the people of this country a Budget which sets out the matters it wants to raise by tax in order to pay for the various programs it wants to carry out. It is not for the Opposition to come so hot-footed, after a defeat in an election, and tell the people that the Government is not entitled to claim the moneys to carry out the programs it insists upon. In this very interesting lecture, Senator Evans went on to say at page 3:

. . . generally I believe that it would be unwise for the ALP to oppose to the point of defeat Bills with which we disagree, unless there are quite clear grounds for claiming that the measure in question is not only obnoxious but one on which the electorate has had no opportunity to pass judgment at the previous election. To do otherwise is to revert to the law of the jungle that prevailed in 1972-5, when-quite apart from supply-more Bills were rejected or emasculated by the Senate than in the whole previous seven decades of Federation.

The Opposition probably wants to beat that record, and perhaps it has in mind that it would like to defeat a lot of Bills. However, it must bear in mind what the very able Senator Evans, who after all is the shadow Attorney-General, has suggested are the principles on which it should base its activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Reprehensible conduct.

—Yes, I am afraid it would be reprehensible conduct-language which I seem to have heard before somewhere. It is also worth bearing in mind the comments made on the Labor Party's suggestions of its new policy by the Australian Financial Review of 20 August, in an interesting editorial headed 'A Labor Party of Bourbons'. We all know where the Bourbons, who never learned anything and never forgot anything, come in. In the course of this editorial it is said:

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the simple reality is that to refuse a Government the power to levy whatever taxes it wishes within the limits of the Constitution is to deny it the power to govern in modern terms. The essence of modern government is economic policy, which involves the setting of levels of both expenditure and revenue.

Surely that is simply the fact. Surely it is also the fact that the Labor Party, in saying tonight that it will try to defeat the provisions, is doing something quite contrary to that. It is denying a government its right to its very existence. Opposition senators ought to be careful that the Labor Party is not so exposed by hypocrisy that it will lose all faith it has in its own community. The Labor Party has a platform.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot lose what you have not got.
—The figures show that some people support it. The Labor Party has a national platform, and that platform commits the ALP to seek amendment of the Australian Constitution:

SPEECH.PARA: to ensure that the Senate has no power to reject, defer or otherwise block money Bills.
It refers not just to Supply but also to money Bills, and those are Bills which provide money for the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you support that?

—No, I do not see any necessity for the Constitution to be changed. I think it is time we had conventions adopted by Parliament which regulate the very rare occasions when that power should be used. I have advocated that publicly for years.
—Who decided that-a drunken Governor-General and Malcolm Fraser?

—Let us not be paranoid about it, Senator Gietzelt. Let us try to be understanding. The fact is that the Labor Party has set out in its platform the very things it would do. This may be a segment of revenge because it wants to get back where it was. If it does want to do that, then I suggest that those in the Labor Party who take that view are taking a very short-sighted view because their party platform indicates differently. Members of the Labor Party have publicly argued this view. They have made no such distinction between Supply and money Bills at all. At the Constitutional Convention, which is one of the most public places where these matters have been debated, a motion was moved by the Hon E. G. Whitlam.
—Who?
—A former Prime Minister and Leader of the Labor Party. The motion was in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: That this convention recommends that the Consititution be amended so as to remove the power of the Senate to reject, defer, or in any other manner block the passage of laws appropriating revenue or moneys, or imposing taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Senator Coates says 'Hear, hear!' That is what the Labor Party wants to do. It is not distinguishing between Supply and money Bills. That is the most recent Button-like invention. In the course of the debate on this resolution, which went through, the Honourable Lionel Bowen spoke strongly about it. In showing that the lower House is the one which should be the House of Supply, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, it was clear, was it not, that the founding fathers of this knew there had to be some opportunity for the Senate to look and to make suggestions on the question of supply, but in all other respects, the Senate had complete power. You might advert to some of the debates of the 1890s, and you see there expressions such as these, 'There can be no two Houses of finance', 'There must always be the one House of finance', 'It has to be the House of the people, there can be no other House, otherwise it is disastrous', and they were the words used.

Now it appears that the Labor Party wants it to be also the House of finance. It wants to take the opportunity of changing the Budget and removing great slabs of it that are important to the Government, and important to its decisions. Unfortunately Senator Button has now gone, but he was at the Constitutional Convention and he spoke in support of the Whitlam motion, which referred so generally to these things. Of course, Senator Button was not there when the vote was taken; he was unaccountably missing. We had that experience during the voting last year on the Freedom of Information Bill. He sometimes disappears. Perhaps he was under a chair or something, but he was not there to be counted.

There is another important aspect of this because the Labor Party is now changing its tactics. Unfortunately, tonight it is not getting the support of the Australian Democrats. It is important that we bear in mind the new strategy which the Labor Party has been pursuing for a couple of years. It has been described as the Blewett strategy and is named after Dr Blewett, who is a distinguished member of the other House. This strategy has been described in an article by Patrick O'Brien entitled 'Constitutional Conflict in Australia'. He speaks about the discussion paper, which I have here. The discussion paper, which Dr Blewett prepared, is headed 'Dunstan shows the way in constitution reform', and it appears in Labor Forum. According to the article, in the discussion paper Dr Blewett advocated:

'a unitary constitution in that indisputable legal authority will be vested in a popularly elected national assembly'. This is necessary in his view since 'elected national majorities and the pursuit of the national interest are constantly frustrated by the diffusion of power under a federal system'. Therefore, 'federal Labor must seize any opportunity that will serve the long-term goal (of a unitary state), even if there are short-term political gains to the enemy'. He added that 'any proposals which contribute to Labor's strategy should be accepted, however soiled their initiators, and however Labor's opponents may gain in the short term'. He added that 'the ALP should avoid spelling out the goals in minute detail, so that the party leaders can seize the opportunities of the moment to advance their basic strategy'.

So it can be seen that those sort of tactics are being used by the Labor Party, and that is why it is now twisting and turning and changing its strategy and saying: 'Yes, this Senate should throw back money Bills'. Let me say that there are other ways. I want to quote from the book Senator Evans' edited entitled 'Law, Politics and the Labor Movement'. When referring to constitutional strategy for 1981 he pointed out one of the measures that should be taken. He states:
As has been suggested earlier, one of the first measures of a Labor government could be an Appropriations Bill providing for the basic costs of government (with an inflation clause) for three years.

In other words, he is saying that we should cut out Parliament and have an appropriation covering three years. He and Dr Blewett hoped they would have the opportunity of controlling the finances if they had gained government at the last election. That was the tactic which they had in mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the first sentence again. It is one of the options available.
—One of the options?
—Do not treat it as the policy.
—I did not read the first sentence. I will read that. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Two further prophylactic measures might also be taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —They 'might be used'.
—Yes, he is advocating that. He states: 'As has been suggested' and so forth. Yes, of course, that 'might be used'. He is the one who is raising the matter. He is the one who is putting it forward.
—You do not ever keep the policies you make.

—I can understand that the honourable senator is unhappy about that because it must be a bit embarrassing. Very interestingly, bearing in mind that Senator Evans hoped to have a Labor government in office, he went on to point out in this article, that:

SPEECH.PARA: These specific guidelines-
which he spelt out-

need to be spelt out in relation to two specific challenges or threats posed by a conservative majority in the Senate: first, senatorial mutilation of Labor's legislative program; secondly, a senatorial veto over supply and thus over the continued existence of a Labor government. These two challenges are likely to be sequential: mutilation of Labor's program is likely from the outset; an actual challenge to the existence of a Labor government is unlikely to occur within the first year.

We can see happening here the desire to do the very opposite. The Labor Party has not gained government so it wants to see the mutilation of a Budget which has come before us. It wants to take away the things which the Fraser Government needs so that it does not have the money to do what it feels it needs to do in the community. Then, later on, when it is frustrated, there will be a challenge. Consequently, the Labor Party's newly exposed idea, which is coming unstuck tonight, is one which we must expect.

TALK.START.PARA: —When will you get on to the Budget?

—I am talking about the whole Budget strategy. The honourable senator does not appreciate that fact. I am glad to see that the Australian Democrats have not fallen for this line tonight. After all, they coined the expression: 'Keep the bastards honest'. I suppose the Australian Democrats are capable of looking in the direction of the Labor Party and are helping us to keep its members honest as well. As Senator Mason pointed out tonight, the Australian Democrats have made a declaration that they will not use their voting numbers in such a way as to cause the blocking of Supply or money Bills in a manner that would prevent the majority party in the House of Representatives from governing. I suggest that that is a consistent attitude that ought to be taken by the Opposition senators on both sides.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget is designed by the Government in an endeavour to continue the progress that has been made in developing this country and the recovery which has been slowly occurring but not without great difficulties because of excessive wage demands at various stages. That sort of growth and development needs the support of the country. The House of Representatives is the House of the people where the majority wish of the people resides. It does not behove the Opposition in this country to try to deny the budget and the Government's right to pass it.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

The speech read as follows-

This Bill is a machinery Bill. It is designed to amend the Air Navigation (Charges) Act 1952 which prescribes the charges payable in respect of the use by aircraft of aerodromes, air route and airway facilities, meteorological services and search and rescue services maintained, operated or provided by the Commonwealth. The purpose of the Bill is to vary the rates of air navigation charges-ANCs-payable for aircraft operating in all sectors of the aviation industry. It is proposed that the variations should be effective from 1 October 1981.

The variations proposed in the rate of ANCs are to reduce the rates applicable to the international sector by 5 per cent; to increase the rates applicable to the domestic airline sector by 12 1/2 per cent; to increase the rates applicable to the regional airline sector by 25 per cent; and to increase the rates applicable to the general aviation sectors by 20 per cent. If these proposals are acceptable to the Parliament, it is estimated that revenue to be earned by the Commonwealth from ANCs in 1981-82 will, together with payments made in that year for 1980-81 operations, total $115.76m. This compares with the $95.89m received from ANCs in 1980-81. Further, the levels of increase proposed for the domestic airlines should have a minimal effect on air fares as they should increase airline costs by about 1 per cent for regional airlines and about 0.5 per cent for domestic trunk airlines. The impact on total costs faced by general aviation operators is also expected to be minimal.

Honourable senators will be aware that since 1961 the Government has had a policy for the eventual full recovery of the costs properly attributable to the air transport industry for providing and maintaining the aviation infrastructure. Full recovery of attributable costs was first achieved in 1975-76 in respect of the international sector. While this sector has continued to be fully recovered, the rates of ANCs for international operations have not been varied since 1 December 1976. Further, in the 1980-81 Budget, the Government announced that over recovery in this area should be credited to the cost recovery program and applied to the development of the aviation infrastructure. The Government has decided that there should be a reduction of 5 per cent in the rate of ANCs for international operators effective from 1 October 1981. While there will be over recovery in this sector, the Government re-affirms its 1980-81 decision on the treatment to be afforded over recovery from this sector of the industry.

It should be noted also that the Australian charges for international operations compare more than favourably with those imposed overseas when the comparison is made on the same basis. Australia, unlike most overseas countries, imposes a composite fee which covers landing fees, parking fees, terminal air traffic control and en-route aids and services et cetera. Overseas, these elements are often the subject of separate charges which can be raised by different authorities, and in some cases they may vary accordingly. Honourable senators will recall that in the 1981 airlines agreement, the Commission and the company recognised that the Commonwealth is entitled to fully recover its infrastructure costs. Both airlines agreed to facilitate the implementation of measures designed to achieve this objective. Their agreement was subject to the proviso that, allowing for minor variations between the years, the Commonwealth did not seek to recover more than 100 per cent of its costs. Moreover, to achieve this objective, the agreement does not limit the level of ANCs which the Commonwealth may impose. The decision taken by Government to increase the rates of ANCs for the domestic trunk airline sector by 12 1/2 per cent is in accord with the agreement and should result in a recovery rate approaching 100 per cent in 1981-82.

Last year the Government decided that there would be no change in the level of air navigation charges for both the regional airline and general aviation sectors. These charges, however, were to be reviewed in the light of the study of the general aviation sector. As honourable senators will know, the Government has not accepted the cost recovery recommendations of that study, although the rate of charges will continue to be reviewed annually. The Government has decided to increase the rate of air navigation charges by 25 per cent and 20 per cent for the regional airline and general aviation sectors respectively. These rates of increase should result in similar rates of recovery to those achieved in 1980-81 for those sectors. For the information of honourable senators, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a paper setting out the cost recovery rates for the civil aviation industry by sectors and in total for the ten years commencing 1970-71.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the interruption by Senator Peter Baume to introduce several Bills the Senate was supposed to be debating the 1981-82 Budget. Having listened to Senator Missen one could be excused for thinking otherwise because the honourable senator did not deal with the subject matter before the Senate. He in no way set out to defend the Budget brought into this Parliament on Tuesday of last week. He set out to discuss matters outside the Budget considerations.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to deflect from my criticism of the Budget other than to say that it is a pity that the speech Senator Missen made this evening was not made during 1974 and 1975 when on numerous occasions he was prevailed upon to cast his vote to deny the Australian Labor Party money Bills and Supply, occasioning two premature elections following two double dissolutions of the Parliament. Instead, of course, he lectured the Senate this evening about the righteousness that the Labor Party ought to have in respect of the way it deals with its responsibilities to the Australian people. He sought to defend his Government and his party's attitude. That attitude was restated as late as last week when Prime Minister Fraser again went on the public record saying that he would do again in 1983 what he did in 1975 when he assumed the leadership of the Liberal Party, when Senator Missen, Mr Fraser and the current Speaker of the House of Representatives, Bill Snedden, moved to defer and defeat money Bills and deny Supply, measures which were essential to the Labor Government's mandate and operation during that period.

It is quite hypocritical of Senator Missen to ignore the fact that he was one of those who denied the Labor Government the money Bill in respect of the Medibank levy, which was part of the Budget strategy for 1975. For him to say that the Labor Party in the Senate ought to recognise the basic principle that the Senate ought not deny to the majority party in the House of Representatives its mandate to rule leaves me virtually speechless. It is hard to believe that a person of his stature in the Parliament can come into this place and suggest that there is something wrong with the Labor Party's attitude when all we have sought from the Liberal and National Country parties is determination that they will not repeat the events of 1974-75, that they will put to the Australian people a referendum which if accepted would enable us to avoid the disasterous events of those years when a government that was given a mandate in December 1972 had to face the people three times in an attempt to stay in office. Mr Fraser is not prepared to give that undertaking to the Labor Party and to the nation. It seems that Senator Missen ought to be raising that question in his own party room and not lecturing the Labor Party about how its members should behave in this place.

Of course, we are sickened by the manner in which Senator Missen referred to the approach of several of my colleagues to this matter in public debates about problems occasioned by the attitude taken by those who claim the right to rule and uphold the born to rule concept that is so much part of the conservatives of this country. When my colleagues seek in various other public forums to debate these issues their comments are supposedly used to decry the Labor Party's current attitude in respect to the sales tax Bills which will shortly be before the Senate. Any decision that the Australian Democrats take will rest on their shoulders. It has to be said that the Labor Party had a mandate in 1972 to introduce a universal health scheme and it was frustrated by the conservatives in this place. The Liberal Party and the National Country Party do not have a mandate for indirect taxation; quite the contrary, as I will show. The Treasurer, Mr Howard, specifically spelt out that in no way would the Government introduce a new form of commodity tax or retail tax or any other form of indirect taxation during the life of the third Fraser Ministry. I was surprised, saddened and sickened by the hypocrisy of Senator Missen tonight when he devoted the whole of his half-hour speech to attacks on the Labor Party's attitude to a new form of taxation which will affect the underprivileged people in our community and said absolutely nothing about the Budget itself. I will leave the matter at that because I want to speak about the disastrous Budget that has been brought in for the consideration of the Parliament.

Budgets, as we know, do not themselves control the economic conditions of the country. This is especially true for a government like the present one which spreads its economic decisions and announcements over a period. This is particularly so when we think of what the Government has done in recent months-the razor gang's cuts, the recent interest rate changes and the health scheme changes announced earlier this year. All these factors have their effect upon the economy and upon the daily life of people. Nevertheless, the Opposition considers that the Budget remains as a major statement on and enaction of the Government's economic philosophy and its attitude to the Australian people. With the 1981 Budget the Fraser Government has shown clearly that it has a contempt for the people and a callous disregard for their welfare. With this Budget this Government has shown that it is once again determined to ignore the problems of housing, education, welfare and health and the needs of most Australian families. It has shown an utter contempt for the legitimate demands of young people for employment and real unemployment relief. It has shown that the dire poverty faced by the homeless, by invalid pensioners, by Aborigines and by others does not even figure in its scale of concern in this Budget.

On the other hand, the Liberal and National Country Party Government has shown again that it is concerned with the demands of the wealthy corporate sector. It has shown that it is determined to continue the policy of redistributing wealth to this sector away from the ordinary Australians and those in need. This Government has shown that it will maintain a campaign against wages while remaining lax about profits. It will increase the tax burden on wage and salary earners while easing it on company profits. While dampening down overall economic growth, the Government continues to welcome largely speculative and inflationary foreign capital inflow on a huge and increasing scale. The needs of the people are being pushed aside to encourage foreign speculators in an uneven, unplanned development of resources, a squeezing out of local manufacturing industry, a pushing aside of the public sector. The vast majority of Australians are being forced to pay for it.

Let us look at some of the main features of the Government's economic policy as expressed in this Budget. In its summary of economic conditions and outlook in Budget Paper No. 1 the Treasury identifies 'the much heralded resource-based investment boom' as the key in the development of the Australian economy. The Treasurer himself notes that 'the resources investment boom is now proceeding apace'. It is undoubtedly responsible for a major portion of the $6,500m foreign capital inflow in 1980-81. Much has been made of this resource boom and its supposed benefit to Australia. But we had an unusual statement from the Acting Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, on Friday when he dealt with the problems of this so-called boom. He was critical of the fact that the Australian people had had their expectations raised by the boom. He said that the effects it would have on the Australian economy were being overestimated. Firstly, it is highly inflationary. Sources, which are as conservative as stockbrokers Bryan Moore Day and Journeaux, have noted this. So too has the business journal Business Review Weekly. In an article this week on resource development Stuart Simpson said:

The Government's rhetoric on the boom also fuelled the expectations of foreign investors. The extensive overseas PR campaign by Government Ministers over the last three years rubbed off in 1980-81 with the huge capital inflow . . . The money supply overshot and the Government resorted to the shock tactics of a rapidly appreciating currency and big interest-rate hikes.

Secondly, with the rundown in local manufacturing and this capital inflow it further slots Australia into a dependent position in the international economy. I think that is a regressive step. Thirdly, it involves a major dislocation of industry, development and the work force. The article in the Business Review Weekly had this to say on this matter:

It is difficult to see how the gains from the development could be uniformly spread. Of the $33,000m (in resource investment by October 1980) two thirds is mining and one third manufacturing. Three quarters of the manufacturing investment is in the aluminium, alumina and bauxite areas . . . Nearly half of the mining investment is in oil and gas, the bulk of which is associated with the North West Shelf project. A similar proportion is in coal.
The Business Review Weekly went on to explain what this means in terms of deformed regional development. It stated:

The investment activity is concentrated outside the more populous States. NSW, Victoria, Tasmania and SA would . . . get at least 25 per cent less of the investment than if the investment was spread uniformly. Victoria will get only 28 per cent of its fair share, but Western Australia will receive nearly four times more investment than its population share, and Queensland nearly double.

In summary this resources boom will not benefit the mass of Australians. At least Mr Anthony has had the courage to say so. It should be made very clear that the Australian Labor Party seeks to encourage a viable mining and mineral processing industry in this country. But this cannot be at the expense of our welfare programs and policies or of our manufacturing industry. It must be allowed to develop alongside these things in a planned and proper way. Yet this Budget pushes aside these needs to welcome uneven foreign investment and speculation. This is the reality behind the words of the Treasurer when he said:
The Budget will curb public sector demands on real resources at a time when those resources are being keenly sought . . . by the private sector.
In reality this is what the Treasury sought to establish when it stated:
. . . on the assumption that appropriate domestic economic policies are pursued, the current account deficit should again be readily financed by capital inflow.

In other words, provided spending on services to the public is cut, wages are depressed and the social wage is slashed, we can allow this inflow of inflationary capital. These are important matters for the future of our society, for the living standards of our people and for the proper development of our community. Yet not a word was said about this by Senator Missen and other honourable senators on the Government side in their contributions to this very important debate. It looks as though those who are waiting for the boom to benefit the vast majority of people had better think again-that is the advice of Mr Anthony-because under this Government there seems no chance that this development will be planned and co-ordinated to meet social need.

Let us look at taxation in respect of the current Budget. Both direct and indirect taxation remain a major weapon for the use of the Government in this process of unfair redistribution of wealth. As leader writers in many newspapers have noted, this Budget is again a high taxing Budget. The hypocrisy of Mr Fraser and his colleagues is almost beyond belief. They claim time and again to be in favour of reducing taxes and cutting so-called big government, yet add burden upon burden to the average weekly income. That is so particularly in respect of the wide ranging number of goods that will be affected by the sales tax proposition. Clearly, this Budget emphasises that the Fraser-Anthony Government is a high tax government.

Last year we saw the introduction, for example, of the petrol pump tax in the form of the oil levy. In April this year the Treasurer announced that the Liberal Party election promise of half tax indexation reiterated by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) only six months before was to be abandoned, and that, to use the Treasurer's words:
In future, taxation adjustments are to be determined on a discretionary basis having regard to economic conditions.
In other words, he says: 'We will give you tax assistance when we want your votes.' If that is not a form of corruption I do not know what is.

Then we have the most disgusting indignity of all. On March 12 this year, Mr Howard stated that the Government would not proceed-I point this out to the Australian Democrat senators-with a new broadly-based indirect tax 'without providing a noticeable offset in personal tax reductions'. For a party that was elected and given support on the basis of keeping the bastards honest, the Australian Democrats are letting down the side by suggesting that they will take a course of action which will lead to the Senate making a request of the House of Representatives to make certain amendments in respect of the Bills on sales tax and that when the Federal Government says it will not play ball, we, on this side of the House, will meekly accept that decision. That, in my view, is not keeping the bastards honest.

Indirect taxation has skyrocketed in the form of the new sales tax levels announced in the Budget. This over-the-shop-counter tax-that is what it is; it is a broadly-based retail tax-will net the Government an extra $892m in a full year out of the pockets of Australian consumers. I stress the matter of taxation measures in the Budget. This is a Budget which has been described by Mr Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association as the worst he has seen in 34 years. This only adds emphasis to the statement made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) last night in the House of Representatives when he said that it is the worst Budget he has seen in 20 years and is one which, by its taxation measures alone, will increase the cost of living by over 2 per cent this year. So much for a government pledged to an anti-inflationary policy. These taxation measures are important because they place the extra burden upon consumers, the ordinary people buying ordinary goods and not on Mr Fraser's wealthy friends and financial backers.

These measures can only result in a real drop in consumer spending adding to the problems of an economic downturn. One only has to read the financial comments by persons who have no association with the Australian Labor Party, by people who are normally the backers of this Government, to see the criticism that they are making against this Government's sales tax proposition. On Budget night, Mr Howard said:
. . . the new revenue proposals which I shall announce tonight will help to broaden the tax base and this . . . will enhance the potential for further personal income tax relief in future years.

Does the Treasurer really believe that we will be fooled by this double talk? Does the Treasurer really believe that the Australian people can be fooled by having their living standards reduced by these forms of taxation? There has been a vast increase in pay-as-you-earn taxation; there has been an imposition of new taxes on commodities. Does he really believe that we will accept his words which are so contrary to what he said in past Budgets and in pre-election periods, that we will be able to have income tax relief in future years. Does he really think that we cannot see that the small tax handouts that he may give us in a few years time-perhaps just before the next election-will be, in reality, swamped by the huge tax ripoff that he is taking from us now. One newspaper observer noted:

The Government is not concerned to stay honest-it is worrying about how best to perform conjuring tricks with the taxpayers' money so he can be made to think he is getting tax relief when he is just paying out in another, less open way.
That item appeared in the Age of 19 August 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2201) Senator Evans asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity both as Attorney-General and as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The question concerned possible amendments to the Australian Citizenship Act 1948, in particular to those provisions determining citizenship by reference to the person who is the 'responsible parent' described as the father in most circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The Australian Citizenship Act 1948 defines the responsible parent of a child as 'the father of that child, or, where the father is dead or the mother has been given the custody of the child by order of a court or the child was born out of wedlock and resides with the mother, means the mother of that child'.

A review of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 is currently being underaken and, in the course of that review, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has asked for amendments to be prepared in order to eliminate any provisions which now discriminate on the ground of sex.

In the meantime officers of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs have been instructed that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is prepared to use discretionary powers conferred upon him by the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 to approve the grant of citizenship to children where he is satisfied that the child is in the custody of the mother applying for him or her to become an Australian citizen and where the child would be at a disadvantage if he or she were not granted citizenship.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2797) Senator Watson asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, the following question:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs monitoring the import of textiles and textile goods from New Zealand? If so, is the Department aware of certain dumping practices, especially in the woollen worsted yarn area? I cite the case of twofold 22s worsted, which has a domestic price in New Zealand of $14.97 and which sells in Australia for $10.40, plus or minus 30c. The same Australian produced yarn sells for $12.40. Is the Minister aware that imports of worsteds, excluding handknits and woollens other than handknits, and carpet yarns, rose from 170,495 kilos in 1979 to 359,435 in 1980? I ask:
What effect is this having on the local industry? Will the Minister take this into account when negotiating the free trade deal wih New Zealand?
The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Department of Business and Consumer Affairs is not currently monitoring imports of textiles and textile goods from New Zealand, although it is aware of an increase in the volume of imports of woollen worsted yarns in the period 1979-80.
The Department has not received any complaint from the local spinning industry concerning alleged dumping of worsted woollen yarns or similar goods from New Zealand.

Before the Department can initiate an anti-dumping investigation it is necessary for the appropriate Australian industry to submit a formal complaint substantiating, prima facie, that imports of the subject goods have been made at dumped prices and that these dumped goods have caused, are causing or are threatening material injury to an Australian industry.

If, following a formal complaint, the Department accepts that a prima facie case exists, the New Zealand Government authorities would be notified and the Australian Customs Representatives in New Zealand would conduct the necessary inquiries to establish the normal values for the goods in that country.

Should these inquiries confirm that exports have been made to Australia at dumped or subsidised prices the provisions of Article 10 of the New Zealand/Australia Free Trade Agreement would be invoked and Australia/New Zealand Government consultations to resolve the dispute instituted.

During negotiations with New Zealand concerning the development of a closer economic relationship between the two countries, the Australian Government has taken account of the interests of Australian industry as a whole as well as consulting with industries most likely to be affected by a closer relationship. Negotiations with New Zealand have not yet been completed, but any closer economic relationship which might evolve would be expected to bring benefits to both countries.
